It's not just school. Learned helplessness is often passed on from parent to child. When a child wants to try something and the parent, who was discouraged from trying things by their parents, says "that's a bad idea" the child learns not to try, and eventually stops asking. Fortunately I had parents who didn’t give a crap what I did. I always ask myself: "What's the worst that can happen?" thereby assessing the risk vs. reward.

You had me until you gave a plug for The Four Hour Work Week. From what I can recall (I read the book a long time ago) he bragged about how successful he was in sales working a few hours a week from different locations. I think he also gave frequent plugs to some outsourced concierge service (I wonder if he was compensated for that blatant advertisement). What great work of art or science or engineering has been accomplished working a few hours a week? What if you were responsible for managing a large team or project? I get that hours worked does not equate to productivity, and that a typical work environment can involve lots of less than productive time, but personally I did not find the book useful and felt that it implied that those of us who work regular hours are somehow just less clever than the author.

I take issue with your characterization of employees who consult with their managers rather than making decisions on their own. You seem to imply that they lack initiative. In most jobs these days employees are given little if any latitude in the way that they do their jobs. They are specifically told to consult their managers if any question arises, no matter how small.

Bullsh*t! "I cannot help people be where they want to be, you cannot help people be where they want to be"

Yes you can... However people once they "arrive" quickly forget where they came from, and forget that they didn't get there alone, as much as the individual drive carried them forwards.

The exclusivity, elitism, and closed door approaches of most industries, especially entertainments industries, that will be the death knell of those industries.

So yes, people do have to do it themselves, build their own thing, and feel alone in what they do... Because the alternatives are work a BS minimum wage job, go on benefits, or waste your life in academia.

The digital landscape was supposed to address these barriers, but now rather than appear on the internet with a website, you need visibility accross a multitude of platforms to stand out, and then those platforms have control over whether your content suits their political agenda...

And I say this after having gone through BS jobs, gaining a degree, attempting to find work in the creative industries, and then starting a creative, self employed business... And it's all one big scam. The world moves at the controls of megalomaniacs who perform the shock experiment on all of us... Covid 19, wars, terrorism, manufactured fears and chaos in order to sell security and comfort. So anything you set out to do is always only going to be within the parameters set by the malicious minds that keep us all scrabbling around for scraps.

My advice now? Drop out, find ways to help each other out of this machinated system. Realise that food, shelter, water, and close connections with others are all that matters, maybe with some music and creativity for the joy of doing it. Everything else is simply an enforced social construct to have you chasing the shiny badge of "success"...

I can make you a successful person in just a few seconds watch:

Were you born to human parents?
Are you alive at the moment?
Are you a person?
Congratulations you have succeeded!

Now live your life, stop chasing desires that lead on to further traps. You are at your most free whilst undefined, once you've lost everything then you're free to do anything.

And if by some overlap between any ambition, and good fortune you "arrive" at a place others aspire to be... Don't be the barrier that you once faced, remember where you came from. We all do better when we provide a helping hand to others that have been shocked and traumatised to a point where they no longer try to "leap the fence".

And if you're in a position to see just who is responsible for the shocks we're all bombarded with, the ones who want us all nullufied, and you still have resilience, then that is a true warrior mindset, and you use that to bite their f*ckin hands off! They might be the hands that fed you, but they were also the hands that locked you up and flicked the switch to torture you!

Manager/Employee "story" again...admittedly I have 40 years more experience than this guy, if you are not TRAINING your employees to be self-motivated, to try to solve problems on their own, that's on the managers NOT the employee.
He is right about one thing...I have tried my whole life, not to be concerned with things I could not directly affect, it's hard to do, you will spend your life trying to mastering it, and you will fail, the key is to never stop trying. If you truly want happiness, here is the secret, when you can look in the mirror and can honestly ask yourself, did you do your best today, your best in life, your loved ones, your job, and the answer is YES. You have won.

I have that 'ask the boss' mentality as an employee too. And when I was a manager I didn't have that at all since I was practically autonomous anyway.

But I feel like as an employee it's not that I couldn't think of a solution for myself. I often do. It's just that if I take the initiative in doing what needs to be done and I didn't do it in the way my boss wants it to be done then there would be unnecessary friction.

There have been a few times where I've had bosses that encourage me to make decisions and sometimes fail and with those bosses this 'learned helplessness' mentality didn't exist for me. I'd just get on with my job.

Which is interesting because it's rather like that dog experiment you explained earlier.

I think a great way to think about possible roadblocks in your job is to stop, think about two possible solutions for it and then go to your manager to ask if either one would be a good solution and ask them to explain why. This accomplish two things: you communicate to your manager that you can invent solutions by yourself and you can validate your own solutions. At first, it might be that you fail pretty often but once you do this for a little time you'll notice that your solutions might actually get better than what your manager could have come up with.

I stopped ruminating about all the things that happened to me as a kid, a teen, a young adult; Started looking at all the active steps I took in my life to come to the fortunate place that I am now. Years after this video came out I've stumbled upon it. I'm currently 25, fresh out of college with a girlfriend who's wrapping up her master's degree... we have our whole lives ahead of us. We've understood that we both want to try and break through the lower-middle class upbringing we have (both going to college is more than most in our families have done) but watching this video (among some others from you) made us realize that we have to step outside of our comfort zone and expose ourselves to really accomplish something and/or be acknowledged for it. We grew up being told that going to college would "guarantee" our lives would be better than those before us. I've always appreciated somebody who can step away from the norm to talk about how real life works because sticking to whats expected of you may not always help people reach their potential. Youve been a phenominal channel to watch because youre educational when it comes to science and facts, but also when it comes to general life advice. Sometimes you have to question things, or try harder, or make yourself uncomfortable in order to accomplish even the simplest of tasks, let alone having something significant haooen. We not only watch for learning little facts or science "know how", but we watch because you seem to have grown as a person. Keep up the amazing work! A life isn't made by sitting idle and waiting for accomplishments to find you, but you've also made us understand that working as hard as we can while only communicating with two or three people doesn't allow for growth. We both look forward to, what is hopefully, our long lives together... meeting people, learning, helping others learn, and never stopping to accept that we've "found the final solution" to anything. There's always room for improvement, and sometimes it isn't how you'd like to go about it. Thank you for all the education you've given us. I truly hope that you see this comment amongst the flurry of daily comments you get, and it gives you just a little bit of drive to do what you've been doing one day longer. Sometimes one video, or one sentence even, can be the push to make somebody else realize their own potential. I hope one day I can be that catalyst in somebody else's life. Thank you again.

I know a person who is on the autism spectrum.  They work in a factory where they “must follow the rules and follow the book.”  And I was so happy when they managed to make it “work”.  What made me happier was years down the road, though they will never be “the boss”, they actually ask the managers for help but in the advent of no management available to condone or direct their next moves, they actually do Something, anything, to try to fix the problem.  That’s the difference between learned helplessness and… what “normal people” do.

Only, one you have control over.  Thanks for the advice, but you made it.  There are millions that won’t.  They weren’t born in developed countries.  They are not smart.  They are not bad people but they are not going to be financially successful.  It’s dangerous to issue false hope or flippantly say people can all be successful.  There are winners and losers in life.  Try hard, but sometimes it doesn’t matter. I retired at 45 years old after 25 years serving the public.  I think I am relatively successful but people are not that simple as this video discussion suggests.  Chance and the Actions of Others play an enormously huge role in most people’s lives. 7:26 after the second lockdown (in my country) we all had to go back to school like normal, with normal hours. For context: my school had in the lockdown purposefully cut down on school hours, bc they didn't want us to sit behind our computer for the whole day (but i guess in a chair in a classroom is completely different?). I had in the meantime really gotten used to this shortened school day and it really worked well with me mentally, so when we went back to normal hours I succummed over the long days (and not only the long days, but also suddenly there was constant noise of everyone talking and I constantly had to move from one place to another and I couldnt focus on one subject for a long period of time bc suddenly i had to move again) when I got home I didn't have the time or energy to work on any homework.

So I became very angry at the school system and all that. One day we had to fill in this "growth paper" or something, which basically asked how I had been doing and what I could be doing differently next year and what the school could do to help me. Out of pure frustration I filled in "have less school hours", not thinking it would do anything. But then I had a conversation with my mentor (idk if you guys have this on America, but it's basically a teacher you can contact if you need help or anything is wrong. They in general hava a better bond with their class (every mentor has their own mentor class)) and just when the conversation was about to end, she leaned over the table and said: "if next year gets really tough, you can come talk to me and I'll see what I can do."

The next year rolls around I talk to her and now I don't have to follow all school hours and I feel much better, a lot more relaxed and my grades are doing a lot better. So yeah, always assume more is possible than you think. Bc most times it is.

4:54 a kind of stupid example of learned helplesness by school is name checking (at least in my school). They always used to name the kids in the exact same order, and when there would be two kids with the same name, everyone would always ask "which one?" eventhough we kind of already new which one. Still the teacher would always answer which one and we'd move on, until one day a stagaire was checking our names. And when we asked "which one" he said "what do you think". And everyone new which one and so we never really asked again with him. Idk I've seen things like this happen a lot in school sort of situations. But anyway it's just a stupid example.

I don't feel good about this. You compared learned helplessness to when you got stuck, didn't try, and asked someone else to help you. And then you say you have to stop having that mindset, and things that seem impossible are possible. But people, most of the time, learn that helplessness not because  they never tried, it's that they tried Every. Possible. Thing. They could think of, and none of it worked. They'll keep trying to think of different ways to tackle the problem, never giving up, but accepting it while they are stuck in it. I feel that the message you're putting out is "if systems or people are taking away your freedom, forcing you into a situation you cannot get out of on your own, you just haven't tried hard enough. And don't ask for help." I'll tell you what comes to mind when I think of learned helplessness. Victims of abuse. Racism. Sexism. R*pe ulture. Modern day slavery. Poverty. Being poor while working multiple jobs. You can't blame the victims of these oppressive systems, because they're fighting against people with an overwhelmingly unfair amount of power over them, people who use unethical methods of control and manipulation. It's a fact that people working together is more effective than working alone, so I would encourage asking for help in every situation. That's what school is supposed to be for, teaching kids the things they couldn't possibly know on their own. We are a social species that works better when we work together. You don't have all the answers within you, most of the time other people know better than you.

There's one thing I am noticing again and again during my time at university: at the beginning of a project/topic or whatever you're up to, it seems like a huge mountain, impossible to climb and extremely complicated. But once you start working on it, you start to notice that the mountain shrinks, the complexity looses its terror until you have actually mastered your task or finished that project. Then, looking back, you wonder why you we're even scared of it in the first place. Same goes for someone telling you about something that is completely new to you and seems incredibly complex so that you think the other person must be some kind of genius to be able to understand such a complicated matter. In German there's a quote: "Die anderen kochen auch nur mit Wasser." which translates to "The others also just cook with water." and I always remember myself of that when I have this feeling of being overwhelmed by something new.

That's right kids. Drop out of school!
...or, don't. It's not easy, but you will get far more life experience struggling to succeed. My sister and I both dropped out of school at 16 because of the slow progression of public school. We had to work twice as hard to prove ourselves and move ahead. Granted, we got an exceed or die trying work ethic from our parents. Our father, a high school graduate, never got beyond the employee mentality. We on the other hand are self employed and make a decent living, with the ability to support our families comfortably. Our father on the other hand is still working at 74 and paying his bills.
If you're barely passing, or failing in school, you'll be better off staying in school. My sister and I are reasonably intelligent, self motivated, autodidacts. We are not your average high school dropouts. But, if you're like us, and don't have plans to enter a science based field that requires a lot of technical knowledge, there are paths to success in most fields that don't require a lot of formal education. You need only seek them out.

Regarding asking a supervisor whje you encounter a roadblock, I'd argue that it's less of "a mindset" of needing help... And more of "I know that if I just do what I think is best without asking first.. and it turns out my idea was incorrect (important to note that for some managers, even the correct answer is the incorrect answer because they would have done it slightly differently) I'm going to be chastised for going rogue instead of just asking."

I think it comes from an understanding that the manager is the one who's ultimately responsible for the outcome, and as such, it doesn't hurt to just ask so that you won't be responsible instead.

Except, the pivot point is not control.  It is the belief in competence to solve the problem.  The dogs that secondarily had the ability to control the situation, but did not have the belief that they had the competence to solve the problem, did not escape - because of their belief.  Learned helplessness is a component of depression.  However, depression exists as a biology because there is some utility to stop trying to escape when there is no escape.  Energy, frustration and maybe even self-destructive behaviors are saved.  Short-term depression produces a type of disengagement that has utility.  Obviously, there are limits.

When I was in year 4 my parents took me out of school to home-school me, something interesting I just realised is that school had in fact made it very difficult for me to make my own choices. I was never able to do studying without someone telling me what to do and it took me around a year to get over it and I just realised it was learned helplessness. It was definitely damaging and I am glad I know what it was now. After that, I became a lot more independent and studying was a lot easier for me, it was also easier for me to deal with a lot of different real-life situations as I had to do things on my own quite a lot. I think one thing about school as said in this video is that you learn to follow, not to lead and that is probably the greatest flaw in the education system. People are growing up not knowing how to deal with things and are probably struggling with things that would be so much easier if we learnt better. Thanks for making the video, it was really eye-opening :)

I've always quite naturally rejected learned helplessness for myself (which makes me sometimes undertake stupid things beyond my skill set, not necessarily successfully) and I've always rejected it for others - refusing to accept their idea that they can't do something, but doing it in a positive way, believing that they are capable.  
It really pisses people off.  
There's another layer of learned helplessness that many people seem to not want to know that things are possible for them to do, they prefer ignorance and lack of control, prefer not having to be accountable or potentially responsible.  
Is that a deep effect of learned helplessness? 
Does it say something about that person?
Or should we take into account all those life experiences and circumstances that contribute to learned helplessness, and are those the things we need to address in society to fix this huge waste of potential?

this is basically the benevolent lie of self help. if you think you CAN'T, then you certainly WON'T. but if you think you CAN, then you might actually... even though it's a one in a million shot. basically, "you can't win if you don't play". but for some things, depending on the dream, you're probably not going to win. ... but you might. probably not... but maybe. the benevolent lie gives the one in a million shot a chance to manifest.

but one thing that must be remembered in these kinds of things is that the folks who say these kinds of things "made it". in one way or another. there's a SURVIVORSHIP BIAS. others who tried the exact same kinds of things may have failed.... BADLY. but you never hear from them. there's a military quote that goes, "he who hesitates is lost". probably from the lips of a general whose impetuosity won him great victories or one big victory. but there's probably a dozens of other generals who did not hesitate either and they got slaughtered. but you never hear from them.

all this to say that a lot of advice and certainly most of self help is a benevolent lie. sure... it's benevolent. but it's still a lie. ... but maybe.....

A man was passing the elephant, he suddenly stopped, confused by the fact that these huge creatures were being held by only a small thin length of rope tied to their front leg. No chains, no cages. It was obvious that the elephants could, at any time, break away from their bonds and become free, but for some reason, they did not. He saw a trainer nearby and asked why these animals just stood there and made no attempt to getaway. “Well,” the trainer said, “when they are very young and much smaller we use the exact same size rope to tie them but at that age, it's strong enough to hold them. By the time they have grown up, their minds have become conditioned to believe that no matter how much they try, they will never break the rope. They still believe the rope can hold them, so they never try to break themselves free."

It is like wishing the roots of a tree grew leaves or bore fruit.

Imagine 2 parallel universes where the exact same barfight is happening, the only thing different in them is the protagonist. One protagonist might join the barfight while the other diffuses it, and another might walk away etc. If you look at it in entirety; what is different between them? One might have had a different raising, or genetics etc. Do we have control over these things? Obviously no. Whatever i try to think of, i always come to the conclusion that choices are made by previously happened external factors (things you dont have influence over)

You could then say oh well whats lifes worth then? and put no effort into anything in an attempt to disprove the previously mentioned. But ultimately it is once again external factors that dedicate whether or not you end up thinking like that.

If you are interested in this train of thought its called determinism

If you see any flaws in my reasoning pls point them out

The big takeaway from this video should not be that you can do anything you set your mind to. Anyone and everyone has heard that platitude.

The big takeaway should be one that was likely not intended: Look for cases of learned helplessness in others and help move them out of that pain so they know it is possible.

If you are loving pain-free where someone else is suffering, you have a privilege that should be used to help others.

A few years ago I had an engineer sent out to me to diagnose a basic broadband issue. The first guy they sent was young, recently ex-military and placed in telecoms via a sort of quick employment scheme. He took one look at the building, saw the cable entry was above a flat roof, and said "sorry, I'm not qualified to go on a flat roof, they'll have to send somebody else." The next engineer, older and formerly self-employed, saw the cable entry, figured it looked tedious to reach and decided to try something else. He checked the wiring inside the building, immediately identified the problem from there and fixed it. I often think about the difference between these two guys.

So, I have "preached" this message in other words for years. Here is how I put it: Everything in my life is my fault, but then I corrected myself.
Something about the word fault is...off.
So I changed that one word to responsibility.
OMG. That fit like a glove.
Because no matter who is at fault for what is in my life (many times me, sometimes not), I am the on responsible for how to respond, and if I can, point myself in a desired outcome.
Here is where it gets tricky. Because in an emotional moment, a knee jerk comment could have ramifications for years or even a lifetime (and it would be MY responsibility).

Interesting. In grade 1, my teacher asked me to read a sentence out loud to the class. I told her, "I'm sorry, I can't read." I was so embarrassed that I started to cry. My teacher was undaunted and asked me to tell her what the first word is on the page. I said, "The." Then she said to tell her the 2nd word and 3rd word and so on.

It became obvious to me that I had been reading for quite some time. I just had no idea that what I was doing was called "reading." I had internalized my family's opinion that "She can't read, yet" and assumed it was true.

By grade 2 I was reading at a high school level. I learned very early to not allow others to tell you who you are. Especially my parents.

This is great. I’d add that as human beings, one thing we’re good at is convincing ourself that there’s virtue in continuing to take the punishment needlessly.

I was surrounded by university people because of my parents, and there was an incessant message that if you didn’t get a degree, you were a loser.

Finding academic approaches to my areas of interest stultifying, I quit, and went abroad and learned music and language there. It was a wonderful experience, and led to a career as well. Yet for a long time, instead of feeling like I had found my own way and succeeded, I felt like I had failed at college and done the second best thing.

Then I met a student abroad who was supposedly there to learn language and music. He’d been an honors student back home, but in the “high school”way, where he’d always done the tasks assigned but not beyond. This was his first time outside the academic environment. He enrolled in a language course there, and he was OK at taking tests, but he never learn to speak. I remember telling him, “Dude, you are now in the world’s largest Turkish school! You don’t have to learn fruits and vegetables from a vocabulary list in your book; go to a market and look at signs! Take a bus out to a neighborhood where nobody speaks English and go to a cafe. You’ll instantly have curious people trying to talk with you and you’ll have to engage!”

Obviously, that is not the only way to be a university student, But if you are motivated and know how to challenge yourself, seek out resources and information, and sometimes people, there’s no limit to what you can do.

Growing up ive had the message that i was too stupid or naive to understand how to properly do things to forward my life. A lot of this was learned from my mother as she would be overly protective and strict, which kinda made me feel more helpless or like i needed to be guided and taken cared of constantly even if i could physically perform something on my own just fine. Even as a grown adult, i struggle with having confidence in my own decisions and whether or not what im doing is just the wrong or unnecessary action to take.

For instance im at a crossroads after paying off my car payment to finally put my money towards investing in my education somehow. I have a lot of ideas about what i like and a strong pull at least in one or two directions but im still hesitant to really take any steps. I keep saying ill save the money for the courses or that ill do this or that goal first as an excuse to not just jump right in, when i know deep down i totally should just do it. Its slow going but i know predominantly im my own master of my life and its a weird thing to navigate when a lot of what you were taught was to perform and maintain a sense of identity/beliefs that werent even yours to begin with, such as my moms ideas when she raised me.

I dont blame my mom for my current life standing, but at the same time i recognize how much "easier" it wouldve been for me to get ahead in life if id just been given the freedom to exercise my own agency since young, rather than being punished or tethered to a certain way of thinking-- that im not as capable or smart as myself as i ought to think i am. But i am. And this is something im trying to encourage in myself even as a 25 yr old today. Because of this habit of conditioning kids i think a lot of kids who grow up to be adults really cannot think for themselves (i mean we convince ourselves we do but a lot of excuses come into the equation when we explain our limitations) and instead go along on the conveyor belt of "do this because youre not capable on your own, you need this and that to be successful in life". Its all under the pretense of "we are here to help and give you what you need/desire" but in doing that we have been conditioned to not identify our real selves, our true needs/desires thus stunt our capabilities to achieve those things.

I am a service plumber in Chicago. What that means is, I am the individual who comes out to troubleshoot the problem the occupants are experiencing. When I first began, I was literally hand the keys to a truck a told "Go figure it out". At first I was terrified of screwing up anything and everything. I found myself to have an extremely high disregard for my own initial impression of executing the job process. Calling on my manager and fellow plumbers I found they were quite often only confirming what I already knew. After all they weren't the ones on site to see the issue first hand.

Occasionally I'm paired with an apprentice. I love these days. I've a great joy sharing my knowledge with incoming "kids". I am consciously not forthwith information as I know learning to think for yourself doesn't always mean having ALL instruction laid out before you. I purposefully give them a task to do on their own with minimal explanation to basically follow in Edison's path of "I've just found 10,000 ways that won't work". If they give up or to say "it can't be done". This is when they will most pay attention to you solving the problem. They want to be "so right" in their conclusion, they want to see their instructor fail. They will focus on every moment. When done, they tend to forever remember that frustrated event to recall and utilize in the future.

There are 1,000s of ways to do plumbing as long as the same result is acquired in the end (Hot's on the left, water goes down and it doesn't smell).

We all need to think for ourselves more. The "instant gratification" construct in the end is the least gratifying.

Man. Of course it's up to "you" to make it happen. To take control. It's also the truth that there is nobody who actually has to walk the walk alone. It always helps to have a mentor, know someone who can kick in a door for you, but once you're in the door, u better be prepared to make it happen yourself. Once you're there, it's up to you to prove that you have what it takes to make it worth while for the person on the other side of that door.

But there's no getting around it - jobs are found, careers made, partly because you know someone who knows someone. It's not as black and white - that either you make it happen by yourself, or you don't make it happen. It's about using the oportunities you have in people around you to get to where u aim for, wether it's small or big tasks or goals or dreams - without abusing the people that is helping you out. Basically - use what's in your toolbox, and it never hurts to get help.

But I totally get the example with the director that cannot help you get on a set just like that - after all, you kinda need to prove that you have something to do on a set. But there are plenty of more oportunities in general for people who knows people, than one that doesn't know anyone. It's also possible to make stuff happen on your own, but hey that's not how it works many times. And this is not learned helplessness - it's using the tools and connections available to you.

Once a foster child, now a game developer, I can attest to the mentality that plagues the minds of billions of people. It is common to feel helpless. Like we are limited to the mundane, common, and simple life.

But for us Vancouverites, we are regularly forced out of our comfort zone, pushed to excel and to reach beyond that mindset to find something more. To be something more...

Our city is enchanting in such a way that many regularly seek to break free of such bonds to try to achieve greatness.

I have family in Nova Scotia, and I lived there for a time - there is a common theme among the people of Nova Scotia, PEI, NB and NFLD.

Many live in poverty, and yet they are okay with it and most are even content - Satisfied with shift work, minimum wage in a dead end career with no accolades and a life lead with nothing to show at its apex.

What this tells me is it is as much a mindset / knowledge, as it is ensuring you have the right surroundings.
When a drug addict is surrounded by friends that don't do drugs, it is much easier to overcome the addiction.

When a person who has no dreams or goals is surrounded by people who do, again, a similar result is a achieved.

We can extend vastly beyond our mental and professional capabilities, if, much like a bacteria in the appropriate culture, we too are surrounded by adequate and appropriate stimulus.

I actually kind of hate this idea. To an extent I totally believe it and get it, but I don't think it really applies everywhere. I'm just finishing a Bachelors in IT (Google it and all you'll see are articles raving about how many opportunities are in IT, how much it's growing per year etc) and despite 5 years in school and a pile of debt I'm realizing my classes haven't taught me a darn thing I can actually use. I'm more tech smart from experience learning, but that's it.

Now take the job market for these careers. Entry level requires almost always at least two or three years of experience, which used to be gained from internships. Now I find myself getting almost daily declination emails for these internships due to a *lack of experience*. People used to say "Oh, just go get some certifications, they prove that someone with no exp knows what they're doing enough to pass a test" but if you Google about certifications you also find a pile of stories saying how it's a coin flip whether the hiring manager respects your cert, or whether they say "A+ Certified? He had to take a course just to know how to turn on a computer and how to run things as an Admin?? He must be a complete moron!".

From there you think "Well, what if I just teach myself how to do it and make a porfolio?". Sure, You spend 5 or more years of your life struggling through an education and come out knowing sweet FA, now you can take all that wonderful new free time you have to make your future job into an unpaid hobby for a few years. If you're lucky enough, you can even practice what you'd like to get a job doing without having to spend a boatload of money getting the corporate programs they want you to somehow already understand. Most of these things are not feasible to even practice or self-teach in a non-professional environment.

Networking has become a four-letter word to me, because it went from a nice extra thing you could do to make finding a job a little easier to basically a huge and singular requirement to getting a job in a technical field. What I've been able to see of IT is mostly brown-nosing and IT managers who impress me by being able to tie their shoes without assistance, yet I walk in with more than a passing knowledge of the field and the ability and willingness to learn, and I'm shunted aside for someone who has a mean golf game and made friends with the hiring agents..

I'm sure I can apply this to a lot of things, but sometimes the issue really has nothing to do with learned helplessness.

Theres one aspect you are missing. Class. If you have access to capital, be that social, cultural or economic, that you live in a place with prospects, then you can often go beyond what youve learnt as there are more opportunities. If we truly wanted to empower people we would whole heartedly pay tax, support meaningful education and provide people the ability to learn sufficiency and effeciency in their lives. A lot of people can't see beyond what they have learnt at home.

in a world where employers make an exponentially greater amount than employees, it forces employees into this mindset. Hierarchy in pay immediately suggests that the employer has a greater knowledge or capacity to do X (whatever it is). If employees had the same capacity to do X as the employer, the employers income would be unjustifiable. Instead, we justify this inequality with a mindset that says “the employer must know more than I do if they make more than I do” keeping us perpetually tied to the “employee” mindset.

learned helplessness is also heavily propagated through the media and some families, especially to certain marginalized groups. They are told "no matter what, you will be persecuted, mistreated, and misunderstood. Nothing you do will change it". I grew up poor, and my family raised me that way too (it wasn't entirely wrong, this world is built around connections-if you really want a good job the best way to get it is just to know the right people regardless of your qualifications). It's quite possibly why upward mobility is so difficult, generations of learned helplessness get passed on to the children, so that even when a rare case where they do get a chance to move up appears, they won't take it because they are told they can't get it (or that "if it sounds too good to be true, it's a scam")

Yes, our systems of education--and government agencies and corporations and society at large--promote learned helplessness. Even knowing it exists is not enough to overcome it. The difference, for the dogs who were forced to endure, was that someone helped them see that they could get away from the stimulus. There is no real agency or organization to help humans with the myriad forms of learned helplessness. The most important thing is support.

It's not enough to know that you can try. You have to be supported in trying. When the world continues to slap you down every time you try, it's just helplessness. Without the freedom to try, and support in overcoming, what you're espousing is misguided optimism.

Still watching this, but paused it at 3:20 to add something. Great videos, btw.
So, about hitting a road block and it ends up being something you may have been able to figure out yourself. Learned Helplessness in that situation. Many times, not just me, but within others (I studied psychology and deeply fascinated with it, as well as science), is that internal problem solving tends to be different than external. Many times people need what is referred to as a "sounding board"; someone they can vocalize the problem they are stumped on. Many times it is actually better to use someone as a "sounding board" that has very limited knowledge of that subject, because they you are having to simplify all the jargon for them to at least follow somewhat. And that simplification, as well as vocalization, makes your brain view the problem from a different perspective, and the answer becomes rather obvious.
Also, later on about children learning in school, and that becoming Learned Helplessness. Not sure I agree completely, though maybe just another viewpoint. Part of the idea of school is social interaction, not just learning the basic subjects. Teachers (good ones at least) encourage students to ask for help. Group projects are meant to help them work together, share ideas, and expand their viewpoints. Something I've constantly repeated to our son ever since he was little was that any problem, school, personal, relationship, etc, it's pretty much a guaranty that many people have had the same problem of some sort and know the answer. He should never feel like he has a problem he doesn't know the answer to, and be afraid to ask.

This video is so true... There is some vague helplessness that stops me from trying to achieve things. I somehow believe it will not work out even before I actually do it.

One time when I was working at mcdonals all the kitchen staff were complaining about an issue with the bench that was causing problems sliding the burgers down. They didn't line up so they were hitting a little bump and were smashing apart. It was like that for months. One day I cad to cover for the kitchen staff and I found there was a cable stuck between the benches. It took literally 5 seconds to fix and everyone was amazed. There was no effort to it at all. Learned helplessness.

Learning helplessness is to get used to a torturing situation in the past. it is a mental power to make us stronger in the future. However, it has a bad side effect as it could lead us to stay still in such a torturing condition and enjoy it so much or even be addicted to it. Therefore, we have to aware of this addiction and pull ourselves out of it then looking for another option.

I feel like this is not the problem for most of us. I feel like it is not that we do not believe we can achieve the impossible, it is just that we lack that level of desire for the particular thing we are looking to achieve. I certainly believe everything is achievable but I don’t know what I want to achieve...

When I was a teenager I wanted to teach comparative religious studies, like Joseph Campbell, but to teach in a university you need a Ph.D. and to get a Ph.D. you have to spend around 7 years in University, accumulate massive debt, and then worst of all, you'll come out making $50,000 year, which was my starting wage in the Oil & Gas Industry. I was passionate about the career but it didn't make sense financially...

So instead, I made a choice. I realized that there was no rule saying I HAD to have a Ph.D. in order to teach religion... and before long I also realized that most "teachers" of religious studies had no idea what they were talking about. Few if any had actually had a religious experience, few had drunk Ayahuasca, or been baptized, or performed Salah. So, I recognized that my handicap was actually an opportunity. Instead of going to school and following the traditional pattern, only to come out of college as ignorant as everyone else, I could blaze a new trail. I could focus on understanding religion from the inside, through direct experience and research... 10 years later and I have 40,000 subscribers on YouTube and I'm earning about half of that Ph.D. income without the debt.

I'm so grateful that I chose to blaze my own trail to success instead of following the laid-out path. Because if I had taken that path I would number 1: Never have understood religion the way I do now, and number 2: I would have remained in that place of learned helplessness, always looking to someone else to tell me if I'm right or not. Now I don't think I'm right, I know I'm right, and the difference is astronomical.

comment_text: I read the book about ‘learned helplessness’ it was enlightening because I had always made my own success until a certain period of time. It was during the Great Recession that beat me into the ground, I learned helplessness during those 5-7 years. I’ve finally come out of it and am reverting back to my innate drive to persevere and rise above life’s challenges. You can too. Think about what works for you, personally, not what ‘everyone’ else is doing. Jump into life and don’t look back.

In my first year of university I met an anthropology professor who, among other unpleasant things, outright declared that girls cannot perform as interpreters. How do you like that?! As a protest I refused to pass his end-of-the-term exam. His management overrode his decision to fail me because all my other grades were excellent. Conclusion: everything is possible if you don't fall for those jerks' bullsh*t.

I used to be adjunct math faculty at a community college.  I didn't live in an office when not in class, so I gave students my phone number and told students they could contact me between 8 AM and 9 PM and ask for help.  In 10 years of doing this, my phone number was never abused.  Never more than 3 students in a term ever took me up on the offer,  and more often than not, there were none. What you say about school is very true. Adolescence is largely a modern invention.
We raise kids assuming they will always be kids so they spend 20 years adapting to conditions very different from the ones they'll actually have to function in. I think we should promote self-directedness freedom and independence as early as it is practically feasible.
Too much control in adolescence is also one thing that promotes follower personalities thatare vulnerable to authoritarianism and mob mentality.

I think we should look at japan (where even small kids walk around on their own) or various native American cultures (where they get kids to help in the household by teaching them from a young age) - though we shouldn't forget that for all its flaws european-influenced culture has some things that it does well though like promoting self-advocacy & asking questions (or so my sister tells me, an educator who actually studied in japan for a bit)

The military teaches "learned helplessness" more than most. They tell you that you should never do anything on your own accord but can also punish you for not taking initiative when you could have, this makes people confused and almost more reliant on the person in charge. I believe the reason a lot of people stay in the military is because of this. You seldom take initiative, you are enouraged to ask for help and therefore rarely have to take responsibility for yourself.
I did almost six years in the military, now I'm studying mathematics and physics at University, and I'm finally beginning to feel like my own person again.

I came to overcome by learned helplessness organically. I just kept at things that the numbers told me weren't possible. I graduated with no internships but kept applying to companies and got into some of the largest ones for my field. I had really low grades and no real research experience and it seemed impossible to get into grad school for my field, but still ended up in a top 10 grad program for my field. I think this is true but it also ignores the incentive differences between employees and managers. This is obviously a generalisation but broadly speaking managers are paid to achieve goals and employees are paid to follow instructions. Of course showing initiative may increase the chance of a promotion but it's also assuming risk that they don't need for their regular pay cheque.

I would have to agree with that assessment of the schooling system. It does take control and the ability to self-direct away from kids. But, more than that,  it teaches them that conformity is more important than authenticity, and that only a certain (and usually very narrow) set of skills is useful in life.   This is no accident.   It was set up to create subservient, disempowered droids with a uniform set of usable skills that are useful for the big corporations, not themselves.    Waking up to that reality and breaking out of it is the first step to creating your own life rather than living one that the state predefined for you.   I regret that it has taken me to my 30s to realise that, but, at least I did realise it!

Our take away can be think about the long term - how to better your current situation

NO ONE has said about schools what I'd been thinking about them since I was a student better than you did in this video. Including myself.

As the popularity of this channel helps prove, learning is one of the most naturally enjoyable activities a human being can undertake. So why do so many people hate school? And why do the people who love it generally not love it for the learning, but for the rigid structure, the reward for following the rules? Because it's all wrong! Learning isn't about preaching at kids from a lectern. If you get kids to ask questions that THEY WANT TO ASK (give them control), they'll learn much faster and with more excitement and retention. And it's not just true of kids of course.

I once saw a facetious proposal that teachers should be paid on a sliding scale based on how much their pupils retained from their teaching, and I was (facetiously) wholly in favor of it because, with few exceptions, none of mine would have ever earned a dime.

The experiment with the dogs isn't even necessarily about learned helplessness, because the dogs really were at the whim of the experimenters. When I told my previous phd advisor (who was the worst choice of advisor for me to begin with) that I am leaving his lab to work with another advisor (after three years of humiliation and self-deprecation), he told me "NOW? It is too late and you will not make it." This was his last pathetic attempt to save his record for tenured position. That moment, I realized this was always his method with me, making me believe I always need someone to guide me and my choices all make things worse. I changed my lab and my whole point of view in my PhD. I stopped observing my superior looking for a thumbs-up after every direction I took and I enforced my choices when I had confidence that choice worth a try. That changed me from a PhD student with severe medical depression to a human that has taken the wheel of her life back. This video reminded me of that harsh journey that ended well for me (but doesn't always for everyone).

This experience is crazy and after travelling one year in europe I can really understand what are you meaning.
Back when I was in school I was thinking that even learning English was such a goal and even traveling a little bit was crazy. My family was not rich at all and no one in my whole family ever traveled around the globe. ( My grandparents have 9 children so I have many relative).
I even wanted to work for some money and then pay 2 k euro for 2 months in uk with a school exchange experience.

But i looked online I saw some culture change experience and stuff like that, for example I'm using workaway but there are other as well.
Basically you pay nothing, and you can live with a Family in every place in the world if you work with them for some hours. This allowed me to stay one year in Germany and more because I never payed rent or anything ( just transport).
I learned English with just internet, but traveling around I learned French and German which for me is such a great achievement.
Back in school I was not able to say 2 words in english and now in the last 3 years I learned 3 languages with few money.
Not only that, but because I had many challenges ( I changed 11 family in one year ) you learn to do things by yourself and in some situation no one is gonna help you for one reason or another.
So you are forced to learn to take care of yourself.
For instance traveling alowed me to make some connections and having some place where to stay. I had no friends, no relatives ecc.. and I was still able to go to Germany and make so many experience. This is something that you just learn by yourself and no one can teach you.
Never stop fighting for you dream of you really believe it.

What i wish i knew when i was young:

Drinking doesn't make the pain go away, smoking doesn't make anxiety any less strong.
Speaking about anxiety, Alan Watts once said "No amount of anxiety will change the result of what is yet to come."
Crying won't help you, but it may comfort you. Praying won't make you rich nor solve your problems, but it may change the way you look at things and how you treat people, the type of religion doesn't matter most of the time, some want to help themselves, some want to help people, some want to be helped, some want to be seen.
I also wish i knew before that i could be anything i wanted to, if i just paid the price for what i wanted. The ultimate price you pay for getting somewhere is far more than just money, but also dedication, hope, the time you are willing to give to an idea, and the time you would lose if said idea just wasn't for you, only for you to realise out of your desperation that the solution to this problem wasn't abandoning the idea, but rather persisting in making it work.
I wish i knew i had not idea of what love was when i thought i did.
I wish i knew money doesn't buy happines, it just buys and builds the bridge to wherever you want to go, and you can go anywhere you want, to the land of misery all the way to paradise.
Sometimes i ask myself i i'm doing the right thing with my life, with people running past me almost faster than i can turn my head to watch them, while i am stagnated, studying, but still, stationary. I ask myself if i am what i needed to be, what i had the potential to be all along. I ask myself if the child i once was would look at me right now and say he's proud, and i wish i knew right now that this is a mistake. We shoudn't live the past and let the present fly by, i get furious at myself sometimes by my stupidity when i say everything that has ever happened to me was a disaster, the moment i say that i fail every single good memory i have of my life, every laugh i had with my friends, every good memory i have of my family, everything i may have forgot about myself.
Maybe i am doing the right thing, but instead of acknowledging it, all i keep doing is say "What if i was that?". Imagine being something only you can be, and yet you wish to be something else, while you are iluded by the fact that you think it would make you feel better, when, in fact, it would only make you miss what you were. Change the world around you, but don't change yourself when the world stops and demands it from you. Don't accept it.

I know this doesn't have anything to do with the video, but I would like to share these questions and this message with as many people as possible.

1. What do you think happens to someone after they die?
2. Do you think there is an afterlife?
3. If heaven exists, how do you get there?
4. Would you be good enough to get into heaven?

Here are a few questions to see if you are a good person:

1. How many lies have you told in your whole life?
2. Have you ever stolen?
3. Have you ever used God's name in vain?
4. Jesus said that "whoever looks at a woman to lust for her has already committed adultery with her in his heart" (Matthew 5:28). Have you ever looked with lust?
5. If you have broken any of these commandments, would you be innocent or guilty on Judgment Day?
6. Would you go to Heaven or Hell?

The Bible says that "all liars shall have their part in the lake which burns with fire and brimstone" (Revelation 21:8) and "Those who indulge in sexual sin, or who worship idols, or commit adultery, or are male prostitutes, or practice homosexuality, or are thieves, or greedy people, or drunkards, or are abusive, or cheat people — none of these will inherit the Kingdom of God" (1 Corinthians 6:9-10). So, if you are guilty of any of the ten commandments, then you are in trouble when Judgment Day comes! Do you know what God did for guilty sinners so that we wouldn't have to go to Hell?

2,000 years ago, God became a human being, Jesus of Nazareth, who suffered and died on the cross for our sins and rose from the dead on the third day, defeating death. The punishment that we deserve for breaking God's law, Jesus took in our place. He paid the fine that we could never pay so that God can legally set us free by forgiving our sins. He is just, by punishing evil through Jesus’ death on the cross, while being rich in mercy towards us.

What you have to do is repent, or confess and forsake your sins, and trust alone in Jesus Christ. Don't trust your own goodness, because, as Jesus said, “No one is good — except God alone” (Mark 10:18). Trust alone in the savior. The moment you do that, God will forgive every sin you have ever committed and grant you eternal life, and He will give you a new heart with new desires, so that you will love to do what is right. You will be born again. But you must repent and trust in Jesus.

When are you going to do that?

(This doesn't apply to every field) To add my point to the "employee mentality" is that I worked at a few (mostly middle-incomptent) companies and I realised that the average worker who doesn't get much paid, just accepts it and tries to get as many hours as possible while doing average work and taking too many breaks, like low pay, low work. I have the mentality that I'll push myself as much as I can despite low pay, the more competent companies realised that and gave me and increase, also tried to keep me by motivating(by increase) when I wanted to leave but incompetent companies don't notice this so I just left for a better company. I say that it's the same with relationships, you have to have experience with different ones, if your company totally sucks despite your trying your hardest (and be honest, are you always trying to optimize things, workout and exercise so you're in better condition for work, are you trying to find as many mistakes as possible that you can improve on?), your colleagues are trying to drag you down to their level because they don't want anyone better than them because that'd make thme look bad(like, employer: look, despite minimum wage, this guy works a lot harder than the rest, the rest is lazy) and managers don't even recognise it? You should find a better one if you want to make more money with the same hours, but maybe the new one will require you to be a very hard worker and not let you take rests whenever you want, so many people just choose to stay where they are instead where it's more comfortable and become lazier over time because that's what their pay is enough for, minimum wage-minimum work or high pay-high skill. It's not always up to "finding a good company that pays a lot", because that's not for everyone.

To be honest I didn’t know people had this type of mentality... I thought that was stuck in the past, the middle class generation. I guess that’s why I’m successful at such a early age. But yes everything this guy said is absolutely true. You can always go around a obstacle, it may take time and you will fail but the experience that you gain is invaluable and helps you gain that immunity to be dependent on someone or something... school teaches you the mentality of dependency on the teacher for example where you need a documentation for the next phase or a good gpa for a good job that is going to be as robotic as school. And that’s sadly how society has evolved to, a problem without a solution...

I'm from the Visual Art field and that too in a developing country. It's been unfortunate to see this phenomenon at work even in a field where people initially go seeking intellectual and creative freedom. What 'learned helplessness' does in such cases is it creates a silly hierarchical system where there need be none, one which honours sycophants more than people who actually demonstrate excellence ('This field is unstructured, so I might as well suck up to someone that seems to know better.') So, not only is the effect harmful to individuals, but also breeds corruption at the level of community.

It doesn't sound to me, based on your description, like there's good evidence that the pure knowledge that the adults could turn off the noise made them perform better:

It's very likely that some people are less sensitive to noise than others. They would have been probably been over represented in the group of people that could stop the noise but chose not to, because adults often have that kind of awareness of what does and doesn't interfere with their work.

Thus, while the group who could do nothing about the noise were selected at random, so would likely have near average noise tolerance on average, the group thay chose not to turn off the noise would almost certainly include more people who were less disturbed by noise -- a huge selection bias.

All day, every day, in school, you are told to do things you don't know how to do, and told you're a screwup if you can't do them perfectly. The implied message is: "That kid over there got a perfect grade, why can't you do the same thing?" Of course you also might realize that the task you're assigned is in fact almost entirely pointless, so you're torturing yourself if you waste the time to do the task perfectly (because every moment you're on that pointless task you're thinking about better things to do with your time), and you're tortured by the disapproval and other punishments of teachers and parents if you don't work hard on it and get a bad grade. So no matter what you do you're tormented by the school system. Just like the dogs who were repeatedly electrocuted.

Brainwashing prisoners works exactly the same way. Torture them over and over, without reason and without respite, until the mere act of not torturing them seems like amazing mercy and generosity. Then it becomes possible to "reeducate" the prisoner with a new doctrine and explain away the torture as "necessary" to break them from their old ways of thinking. The school system operates the same way, albeit much more slowly. The strict supervision at low grades gives way to more freedom by the time one graduates from college, but the system has still indoctrinated the students into the notion that this is the only way it can be and *the torture is for your own good*.

The only other organization where the time you spend in the system is what matters, rather than *what you achieve*, is prison. And that other system is also designed to affect the mind (albeit it also does a really bad job of it, since they don't get to play with the pliable minds of children).

By the time a child graduates from school, they're taught that even their private bodily functions like using the toilet, are subject to someone else's control. That they need to ask permission to do anything because that which is not explicitly mandated is forbidden.

How convenient for those who really like to control other people!

Furthermore, the school system is composed of people who liked the authoritarian nature of the system as it was, and returned to it so that they could *make it even more like it was*. This is why what is taught in school lags behind society by half a generation or so.

One last note. Never conflate school with education. Education is done for the benefit of the student, usually by the student themselves. School is conducted for the benefit of school, and camouflages itself as education.

Along those lines and rooted in success... business owners and managers are LOOKING for those people that get the job done without any further input. I call it hyper-competency. this is a rather minor case, but at our school, we had an opportunity to get a free trip to japan. this was offered to around 200 students, but only 6 of them responded, likely because most of them (myself included) thought "well, I can't speak japanese, there will be many other people applying for this, I'm probably not going to get it." and so many people just didn't apply. I personally know one of the 2 people who won the trip, and they had never learned any more japanese than how to count to 99, how to say hello, and that was basically it. If i applied, I would've had a roughly 2/7 chance of going to japan all expenses paid, and I missed the opportunity because I thought I was doomed to fail. now, this is a less hidden version of learned helplessness,  but I think it is still relevant. This video has shown me that what I experienced with the japan trip, probably applies to many other things in life. It has shown me that I should give it a go even if it seems unlikely to succeed.

I grew up on the East and from 6 through 21 I suffered psychological punishment, from school bullying, from school teachers discrimination, and from the local residence outing me and putting me down.

I later scored in the 10th percentile of the Canadian population on SATS and other University Aptitude and Psychological Tests, I never was able to reach my potential. In fact I scored quite high on the self abasement test.

While I came to understand why over the years, I'm 72 soon, it is nice to see it explained for others. Thanks for doing a video on it.

I have a real world anecdote that speaks to this video. 3 years ago, I was in a bad place, working as a server, high school diploma but no college degree, living night to night and dreaming of working in a programming job. This has the caveat that I had taught myself PHP and a couple of other programming languages, but had no portfolio to back it up or a degree to prove I knew what I was speaking about. Eventually I said screw it, I'll apply for any job I think I would want without the experience they are asking for on the job application. After only about 4 weeks, I landed an interview with a company that said if you can come in for a coding interview, we can talk. I went in scared as hell, having no idea what to expect and with an extreme anxiety caused by impostor syndrome, and in the very first test: I finished and showed the lead developer who looked at my code and said... "I didn't even know that was possible". I was offered a job that day. I know not everyone can have that experience, but my point is, you have no idea what is possible until you step out on that limb and see if it holds up. You may fall, but damn its worth it. Just TRY, I know its scary and I know there may be rejection, but you'll never know until you step out and see if that limb holds your weight.

I teach courses in psychology and you are talking about internal vs. external locus of control. I am always wary when we go too far into an internal locus of control. the self-help industry is predicated on the internal locus of control and that individuals ultimately control their destinies.

while I do not disagree that individuals should take on responsibility for their lives, I do understand now more than ever, that external events that take place can hinder or help in our mission for success. sometimes these things are simply based on Lock and happenstance not on the individual's drive or motivation.

It becomes dangerous when young people feel that they are doing everything they can but still going nowhere because of random circumstances and a self-help industry is telling them it's their fault for not hustling harder.

so again, I do not disagree with an internal locus of control or taking action, daily action to achieve your goals, but I also do not believe that everybody can achieve anything they want. It simply cannot be the case given the realities of the world.

It is not that employee doesn't want to make a decisions on his own as he/she is feeling helpless, it is because he/she knows that if something goes wrong the employee will get blamed for it. I think one of the biggest issues that I have with our educational system is the way that they teach mathematics to students. Now, before somebody claims that I'm just trying to justify being a bad student well, I'm not a bad student. I receive straight A's. Especially in mathematics. I know that might sound pretentious but math is my best subject and it's something that I really enjoy doing. The reason I do well in math is not because the subject was taught effectively. They do a better job at teaching math in universoty than they ever did when I was in grade school though. The reason I do well is because as a result of self studying I've built a really good mathematical intuition for some of these subjects.

When I was younger, after we learned basic arithmetic math was taught in a way where it was as if they just wanted the students to mindlessly follow the steps that they were told to do. They were asked to just memorize a bunch of information without really building proper mathematical intuition. That is not the proper way to teach mathematics in my opinion. A lot of teachers would give their students a week to memorize the Unit Circle. But if the teacher explained to the students what a radian is and how half of a rotation around the Unit Circle is equal to π radians then the students would see that you don't really need to memorize very much of anything because you can just work out the rest. Now, of course there are some things that you might have to memorize but the more you learn the less you have to memorize. I hear a lot of people say "I'm just not a math person." I believe this might be a direct result of how math is taught in some schools. We as humans are very abstract. So I think it's reasonable to say that if you are a human then you are a mathematical person.

On a sidenote... I'm fascinated by biological evolution, and convinced that our divergence from the ancestral way of life affects us in many more ways than we know or can imagine. Since social status is so deeply ingrained in us, I think seeing superstars on our TV or our computer really puts us down. In nomadic tribal days, you could see the entire spectrum of status; the most impressive people all the way down to the least. With mass media we are bombarded with impressions of the most successful people on Earth, and what social impulses must that not trigger in us, when we're just a baker, or just have a masters degree, or didn't get the promotion? It's gotta be detrimental to our perception of our own status when the common person isn't represented much. Thank God there's at least reality TV and game shows o.O

Things I've learned:
You're going to die, so whatever. It's nice that you can do nifty things now, but reeeeeally whatever you do is a fart in the wind compared to the black hole churning at the center of the galaxy, deciding the fate of millions of worlds. Maybe if you just get over yourself you might be happier. Go look at a flower. There were flowers a billion years ago and there will be flowers on other worlds a trillion years after you die. Flowers are neat.
No matter what cool idea you come up with for your life, it is absolutely dwarfed by all the cool stuff you couldn't possibly have the chance to do. Are you a concert pianist? Pretty dope, but you won't be an astronaut, or a Senator, or an Admiral, or a gymnast touring the world, or the old lady everyone loves who bakes the best cookies, or an old sailor making his way through the Panama Canal on his way to offload his cargo, or the startup tech genius, or that guy who gets all the ladies, or a race car driver, or the engineer building the race cars. So...get over it. Just enjoy the ride.
Pretty sure animals intuitively know both of these things. Humans have perfected an odd state of making ourselves miserable through sheer imagination. We have satellites and computers as a result, and maybe one day that will lead to something. But you're still going to be some dude in his dusty living room getting mad about the news headlines and wishing you had just that little bit more money for that thing that's a bit better than the thing you have. And you're wasting your time.

Prep talk I needed right now, nothing new, but it feels good to be told this to my face.

Here is an example.
My highschool late bell was at 7:35.
At 7:35-7:45 was Homeroom for attendence. A waste of time standing around for the actual bell to ring to walk to the other side of the school in the next 5 minutes for the first period class.
Now the school 7:35 bell was actually set for about 7:32 or 7:33.
I had a 25 minute drive to school and would get there almost at 7:33 everytime. Of course with the bell being early the front doors would lock. The secretary had a window to see who they were about to unlock the door for and would never look up until the bell rang.
I'd walk and they would say what is your excuse
I didnt have a license so i'd say I have no choice when i get here because I rely on my parents to drive me I get here when they get me here. Of course trying to act professsional the laid off english teacher who somehow became the principal would say ITS My responsibility to make sure I get to school on time. The same principal that had several gramatical errors in my college recommendation letter. Double standard here. Their bell is 2-3 minutes early and 250 highschoolers are supposed to accommodate that as if everyone lives by that schools clock that is unprofessionally maintained and the principal is so anal up until the very second of everyones arrival.
And a reminder that class does not start for the next 15 minutes and the teachers also take attendence.
The principal would tell her secretary to lie that she was not in if a parent she did not want to deal with called in advance for a meeting or even to talk on the phone.
You had to walk in unannounced to speak with her. Even then the secretary lied to my mother saying the principal was not in that day. My mother was angry and said she would wait. They put her in the conference room to speak with someone to take notes on what she had to say. Minutes later the principal peaked in to see what was happening to which my mother replied with
"What a pleasant surprise!" "Your secretary didn't know you were in today, you may want to let her know." "Now why dont you sit down here so we can have a little chat."

I think blaming schools is somewhat lazy.  Our society has many other factors that also foster the phenomenon of learned helplessness.  To list a few: helicopter or bulldozer parents, everyone receiving an award, the instant gratification/gamification that rewires neural pathways in social media and games, no deadlines...the list goes on.  Looking at or projecting learned helplessness as a symptom of broken education system is perpetrating a dangerous idea that somehow personal accountability doesn’t play into this.  I like to encourage divergent thinking in the classroom and wish that my students would leave with a stronger belief in themselves. Einstein wrote a little known piece called “Willing Ignorance” which is a phenomenal introduction to a long-since forgotten book, written by his lifelong friend H.G. Teslien. The book, “The Evolutionary Success of Failure” explores the way in which the “optimism bias” (visible in humans and closely related primates) increases costly behaviors and negative outcomes in various population subsets. Despite decreasing the fitness level of the given subset, irrational aspiration and a predisposition toward risk taking increased the likelihood of the population survival through time.

Goal acquisition generally depends on optimistic outlook and optimism is an evolutionary adaptation which rewards a minuscule subset of aspiring individuals by favoring only a small subset of people who remain willingly ignorant to the odds of their success, despite harboring the potential skill and awareness to accurately calculate the probability of achieving their goal(s).

Einstein’s introduction ends much as does the book itself—with a surprisingly dark conclusion that runs counter to the typical “follow your dreams” slogans of positive influencers.

The conclusion is this: encouraging the young and naive to make irrational attempts at exceedingly unlikely payoffs is a feature of the optimism bias which co evolved in continuity with and by reason of the necessity for this bias to reproduced in subsequent populations/generations.

Humans are socialized to be optimistic and ignorant and while we think this is good for people to hear, it’s actually quite costly for the majority of individuals as it is irrational. But long term, it increases diversity of attempt, improves theory of mind, problem solving, short term prediction skills and collaborative competition.

Counter intuitively, role models are essential in reproducing a culture of failure typified by increases in overall incidents of self-identified losses, risk taking and irreversible damage due to trial/error, inasmuch as the increase in the number of irrationally optimistic individuals remains proportional to the increase in population density.

That is, optimism can be thought of as Mother Nature’s way of getting her children to do the very things she taught us better than...because unlike the mortal human, humanity has (at least up until now) has time on its side and evolution favors diversity and duration over the maximization of benefit over the fixed lifespans of the individual.

It's interesting how this gives an entire second type of reason for why breaking challenges into defeatable, testable fragments is the winning strategy.  Not only does it make the task inherently easier, it has this psychological effect.  That is, finding out that you were able to master one aspect of the task trains your brain to identify as someone who masters aspects of the greater task (as opposed to identifying as someone who has never had anything to do with it, and has no chance).  It's like instantly training the dog that it can at least sometimes avoid the shock, and it expects that effort into avoiding the shock will make a difference.

Learned helplessness is part of most jobs. Look at the military where you are not a person, you are a product used for warfare. You don't think in the military or you might not do what is needed. You just do what your told. It is your Superior, your Commander that does the thinking. Then you do what they tell you.

Same for Construction. I can't tell you how many times during my college years when I worked construction to get through college I was told, "Your not paid to think. Just do it the way I told you". Even if I had a better, more economical way to do something, INCLUDING if my way was safer even.

As for the myriad of jobs I have had. I only had a few where I had a manager that didn't WANT to be the one to make ALL the decisions. Even the slightest of decisions had to be run by them. Is it "Learned Helplessness". I don't see it that way. I see it as just tired of the BS. I, like most people I know DO think of the stuff that makes life easier, or the better decisions and answers. We all just don't do it or don't offer it because 99% of our jobs we have had have been under some asshole who does not care except to chastise us for thinking and doing something on our own.

Remember, for many managers, if the employee excels and looks like they know more than the manager, that is a threat to their jobs. Fear that YOU will cause them to get fired and YOU will get their jobs. For others it is just a power trip.

We aren't helpless. We just don't want yet another reason to have the manager be an asshole to us.

Researchers would put dogs into shuttle boxes (long-caged structures the dog could move around in) and would shock the dogs through the floor on one side of the box. The dog, at first could easily escape the box by moving to the other side of the box. Eventually, the researchers adds a wall so the dogs can't escape the shock -- it just sits there, being shocked without escape. Through this the dog learns helplessness over repeated trials and extended periods of time. Even when the wall is taken down, the dog won't walk to the other side and avoid the shocks anymore. It has become so used to the pain that it doesn't even try to escape when escape would be easy.

This research has been used to explain certain aspects of human behavior, especially repeated experience of abuse, addiction and poverty. It takes a long time to get somebody out of this mindset, and is possibly one of the reasons why people get "stuck" in terrible situations.
