I noticed this during my high school computer science principles class. During the first few months of the school year, I'd taught myself c++ on the side so I could start programming independently. Whenever I wanted to write a program, I had to debug it and research solutions until I could figure it out. Our cs class used Javascript in code.org. We would get very simple programs to write sometimes and the code.org environment was very (even painfully) beginner friendly. It would highlight the line that was causing the problem and give you the error in as clear english as possible and had debugging tools; they let you highlight each step of the program as it ran, for example. The programs didn't usually get more complex than using basic concepts like loops and conditionals, but I noticed that whenever most people in my class had an issue with their program, even a minor one, they went to the teacher. I don't think they were dumb (this was an ap class) but they didn't seem to consider looking the issue up or just debugging it. I think the system had taught them for their entire life that they should just go to the teacher if they were having difficulty, and had inadvertently led them to feel helpless at solving their problems.

The quickest way to instill Learned Helplessness in employees (or anyone) is to institute a Culture of Blame. Almost 99% of managers sit around and bemoan and blame the listless unmotivated blobs that surround them, and have No Idea why these people cannot even make the most trivial decisions. If your first inclination is to Figure Out Who To Blame when things go wrong, you have No One But Yourself to blame for this situation.
Know this: It's Not their fault, it's yours. I've worked at places with the mentality that The Next New Hire Will Finally Solve All Our Problems. When you detect this, know that you are entering a Culture Of Blame and your Will To Live will be shortly destroyed.
Got Micro-Management? Yeah, you've got a Culture of Blame.
Do you reprimand people who put forth their best effort, but don't quite reach stretch goals? Yeah, Culture of Blame, and that swirling mass in your office is a Black Hole of Demotivation, sucking in peoples willingness to try... Anything. And YOU are to blame, Corporate Management.
And this may sound like trivial FU Blame Shaming, but I honestly think this Invisible Monster of Learned Helplessness WILDLY exceeds the cost of Traditional Corporate Cost Monsters, like Obesity, Sick Days, Drug use, etc, etc. It doesn't cost Billions, it probably costs TRILLIONS.
It is probably The Biggest Problem in Corporate America (or anywhere) today. Why does it exist, why is it so pervasive, why can't we get rid of it? Because Every Single Person does not want to be seen as WRONG. We ALL have fragile ego's. No one wants to say, "This failure is My Fault", when blaming it on everyone else is So Much Easier, especially for management.
Once a Culture of Blame infects a company, mediocrity, employee dissatisfaction, death of innovation is almost always on its way.
Look at what Jeff Bezos says aboout failure: “It’s not an experiment if you know it’s going to work.” You have to tolerate failure, even celebrate it, or you are doomed.
Learned helplessness might actually be a good thing if people aspire for things that are inherently rare (for example, winning national gold medals, or earning over $1 million per year).

Yes there is "learned helplessness" but it doesn't at all mean "you can do everything you want" and even less "just keep trying forever". Being set up to repeatedly try something you can't do is actually the way you learn the "learned helplessness". And the best way to overcome it is by asking for help.

There's NOTHING wrong with asking for help. Not trying everything on your own, can and will actually help you accomplish a lot more, a lot faster. It's a question of how you ask, and whom you ask. Not surprisingly, if you consider it a defeat every-time you ask for help, it will make you unhappy and less productive. Actually one of the most important skills of any successful CEO is ---> delegating.
Do the things your good at, the things u have to do, and the things you like ---> delegate the rest. There are some things you might have to do on your own, but usually it's a lot less then CEOs believe.
We may not like it, but there's pretty solid evidence that most positions aren't filled with people of the highest competence, but with those who "know somebody" and those who socialize well.

I'm pretty sure, in the western and asian world, a lot more people get stuck, trying to solve delegatable problems on their own than in "leanred helplessness". However, the problem is neither their incompetence nor "learned helplessness" but ---> they're doing something they don't really wanna do. They've been raised into the typcial western and asian blind-ambition, where the most important thing is "be strong, accomplish things, do something" instead of asking yourself "why am i doing this" or "what do i even wanna do" or "is there somebody else who would be happy to do it for me, to our mutual benefit"?

Wasting time on a problem that somebody else would be way more competent to solve is actually a form of "learned helplessness". ---> It's being stuck in inwardly focused ambition. "I have to prove to myself (and prolly my parents that won't even see it) that I can do this." Why do you need to prove it? ---> Because u lack self esteem and waste time and energy on proving things to yourself when others just say "yeah i can do this, but i don't wan't to".

That's the reason narcissistic people like Donald Trump can roll over everybody so easily. They're not smart, they're not educated --> they're only real skill is manipulating others, and using they're ambition and lack of self esteem while having little to no conscience about it. But it's enough. They don't care that everybody else is doing the actual work, they just attribute it to themselves anyways, thus never wasting time.

"divide et impera" - to turn people against each other you need to make them believe that admitting defeat or asking for help is something weak or bad. Yes you prolly can do a lot more then u think ---> the question is does it make sense to do it?

Now onto my TLDR rant on why this is such an important video.

I am 53 years old. For the longest time, I've had ideas, dreams, etc. that I've plotted out in my own mind, sometimes to a great level of detail. But, because of learned helplessness, I've never taken any of them past the point of a neat mental exercise.

I've been blessed to have found the woman of my dreams, to have her be my wife for over a quarter of a century. As you would expect with any relationship, I've made my share of mistakes over the years. But, because of learned helplessness, I've frozen in my tracks in working to mend the fences that I've trampled on, in working to tear down the walls that I've built between us, in just simply apologizing for my neglectful acts. This has put a wonderful woman (and our equally wonderful children) through unnecessary pain and hardship, and led to a life of regrets for us all.

I've been blessed with the raw talents and the opportunities to make a good living in a field that I generally enjoy. But, because of learned helplessness, I've fallen prey far too easy to abusive "leaders" who sought to discourage me for their own career benefits, while refusing to accept the honest mentorship of those who only sought to build me up to my potential. My career is now in a perpetual rut, and because of learned helplessness, I am discouraged from even trying to find a good fit at my age.

Please, anyone who's bother to read this far, do NOT give up on your desires to get the things you want. ERR ON THE SIDE OF THINKING YOU CAN CHANGE MUCH MORE THAN YOU THINK YOU CAN. Learned helplessness is a lie from the pit of hell, and if not confronted, will take your hopes, your dreams, and even your desire to live as casualties.

I'm a public educator. I don't think the issue in schools is not allowing kids the control of their own education and futures, I believe the more damaging thing we are doing is allowing them to "succeed" with no work, and this is how they are learning that there is a "reward" to being helpless. There are too many adults in the school system who willingly falsify student data, give answers to tests, and otherwise do not hold kids accountable for their own education. If you're asking why they do this, that's another can of worms. This is allowing the students to learn helplessness. As long as they know that there will be a way out that is easier than actually doing the work they need to do, what do you think they do? The same thing we all do. We take the easy road most of the time. So these students feign helplessness, and in time even come to believe that they actually are in fact helpless, because they know that at some point a "caring" adult will step in and not allow them to actually fail.  This is incredibly unfortunate, because those of us who are responsible adults understand that for the most part the world outside of school doesn't work this way. But those who have learned helplessness in school, when they get out, expect the rest of the world to step in for them and correct or even take responsibility for their failures, like their former dysfunctional teachers did, and this expectation results in a lot of pain, both for them and for the rest of us.

Nah kids have perfect control over their achievements and how painful it is in school. Just listening in class alone basically completes 80% of the workload. Why not get study work done when you're stuck in class anyways, and get good participation grades as a bonus?

That's what life is all about. Deal with the cards you're dealt, make the best out of them. You have to learn what variables you can control and which you can not control and do the best with what you have control over.
So why try to do useless stuff in class that you can't do properly cause you're...well in class, then struggle with the homework when you're at home? Why not just do that in class (where there is someone who gets paid answering your questions when you don't understand something) and have carefree leisure time outside of school?

School was kind of a pain before, but once I figured that out it was all a piece of cake. School is actually quite easy. Anyone can get decent success, but you have to be willing to actually get something into your brain. Anything is hard when you can't will yourself to do it.
It's a self reinforcing thing. You will yourself to study, studying becomes easier, it becomes easier to will yourself to study, studying becomes even easier.

It's all on you. Don't try to blame the system for your decision to not make it easier on yourself. Don't blame others for supposedly just being smarter and/or more talented and use that as an excuse to do nothing. It's your choice!

I worked on a university nanosatellite program while majoring in physics.
Because a lot of the standard jobs were already filled, I got put into EMI/EMC and space radiation forecasting. I was the one guy who was doing that. And nobody had any clue how to do it. When I asked what I was supposed to do, the answer was basically 'figure out what you have to do.'
Within a year, the rest of the physics team had graduated, and suddenly I wasn't just finding my way around radiation forecasts and component test workflows. I was in charge of a much bigger job. Alone, with no team. And suddenly I had to learn the rest of the physics team's job - neutron interaction modeling and forecasting - and build my own team. Different problems, but ...same fundamental problem. Figure out what to do and how to do it.
Within a year and a half of then, the deputy chief engineer was throwing problems in front of me he didn't know how to solve.
Was I smarter than anybody else, or more motivated? I kind of suspect not. I was just forced to find my own way around a problem, because there was no one else to do it.
Even now it still feels like a unique and unusual experience. In an environment built around reaching bars set by faculty, I was faced with something where part of my job was simply blazing my own path of figuring out how to do my job.

I'm pretty sure happened to me between 2012 and 2014. Then I broke free, made my own choices, started living my own life. Then my flat was taken away from me and I moved back to my parents and the cycle started again!

But while watching this, I also realised that it probably went deeper too, stuff at school that happened to me, rather than me being able to choose...

There's definitely a pattern throughout my life... 🤔🤔

Time to change and choose..

I came out as nonbinary in 2011 and that experience really altered my psychology. Transphobia is obviously still a big deal but at the time most people didn't seem to understand that trans people existed at all, let alone nonbinary people. I had to explain myself to most trans people even. All these things that have happened in the past few years have happened on a scale I genuinely did not believe I would live to see. (I mean, I didn't think I'd live to these past few years anyway but still.) I have done these things to stand up for myself again and again, concluding hopelessness. It is so incredibly disheartening and traumatizing to have people of authority tell you that your belief in your own existence is a delusion.

This is still very much a thing that happens for the most part with most people I encounter, but not like it used to. There's more context to understand and more info floating around that indicates I'm not the only one or maybe even the first one somebody has met.

If I keep fighting for myself it means I am fighting for those like me who have dealt with the same things. If I have to forage that path myself. If I have to wear people down, get a bad reputation because I'm always sticking up for what's right, it's just an investment I'm making in a better future for others.

And yes school does teach learned helplessness. Exhibit A. As smart as I was, I could never succeed, I was good at almost everything before others were and nearly didn't graduate school. Go figure, work the system or fail. Do what I want? Doesn't lead to anything. Only doing what is required of you by others gets you anywhere, can't master their system? Fail. That's it. Where is the alternative? Without money (in my case welfare) you don't eat. System or bust.

When I was a little girl I failed at a few things. My internal dialogue was " I'm not good at things so why bother to try?"... I've carried this through my whole life and have only now realised about my learned helplessness. The funny thing is, I don't try for anything and I've never mastered anything. I've always done just average, just scraped by. The main reason is because I've just not put in that much effort, because putting in some effort would mean I am emotionally invested, so if I failed then... well, the let down would be so much greater!! So I kind of try to fluke things. It has become avoidance, procrastination and laziness. Why try for any success?
Now I need to unlearn this. Make a new reality where I can be ok if I try and yet fail, but at least I gave it a go... You never know I might not fail, I might be good at something. I may find success.
I have to add that the serenity prayer was perfect and I had thought of that myself before watching this video!!! God grant me the serenity to accept the things I can not change ( I may not be good at mathematics and I may fail at maths but that's ok, I'm still loved unconditionally by you God, I am enough), courage to change the things I can (ok I can get around to doing my taxes I'll do it today for my fears won't hold me back), and the wisdom to know the difference.

Hence the rule "Don't got to the manager with problems, go to them with a choice of potential solutions"

Often in the process of considering potential solutions, you'll solve the problem without the manager's help.

Even if you don't come up with any potential solutions, you'll at least have learned how to think about the problem...and the more you practice thinking about problems,, the more you learn about how to do that and the easier it'll be to come up with solutions to future problems.

Exercise the gray cells at least as often than you exercise the muscles, because in the 21st century it's what the gray cells do for you that's more important than what your muscles can do for you.

I flunked out of engineering and almost college altogether because I procrastinated so badly. I have changed majors and schools twice to get a 'fresh start' but third time's a charm, because I finally realized that my procrastination was a result of my learned helplessness.

I started noticing that procrastination was creeping back into my academic life for a third time, and my grades were showing. I finally decided to face it for what it was and I bought a book entitled "still procrastinating?" by Joseph Ferrari. Reading that book showed me that my failures had NOTHING to do with my ability, but with my learned habits and learned helplessness. I realized that procrastination was a symptom, not a disease. It's about how one views himself.

When it comes to asking the manager for help, I do not believe this is an example of learned helplessness and it just an example of Passed-On Responsibility.

When you come to a road block and you know the answer, you aren't looking to be helpless by asking your manager for the answer you already know, you are looking to pass on responsibility, so if that solution "fucks up" it's not your fault it's your managers fault for suggesting that solution.

I believe this was demonstrated in the Infamous Stanely Milgram Expiriment. The same one that suggested how the Nazi's were able to break human morality by pass-on responsibility.

This is something you actually see a lot online, especially with socially insecure people. You see comments that complain (often in an ironic way, but still complain) about things like social anxiety, their shitty school, friends, parents, being friendzoned, being poor, lacking of skills or talent and much much more and I'm always wondering how many of those people actually tried to change that.
You're socially insecure? go somewhere you can be sure to meet people who share your interest, so you don't have to fear that anybody thinks you're stupid because of them, try to walk yourself through situations (in your mind) before they happen to take away the fear of not knowing what will happen. Especially the last one has helped me a lot.
You're feeling friendzoned? Stop whining about it online, decide if you're okay with being just a friend and then be that friend or distance yourself from that person (at least for a while).
It basically comes down to never assume you can't do something if you never really tried. Nobody is good at something just because they have a given talent but because of practice and work. So stop making excuses why you can't do something. Accept your circumstances and make the best of it.

Look into memory reconsolidating in neurology studies.  Essentially, in stressful situations, specific parts of the brain lock in "neural circuits" that remain that way forever -- until the original stimulus (or something very similar) is reintroduced, and then the synapses unlock, allowing for new learning to take place.  That's why those dogs needed to be reintroduced to the shocks and then shown that they could get away from them before they could change their behaviors.  This is also particularly important for the treatment of trauma-induced maladaptive behaviors in people as well.  Some portion of the experience needs to be reactivated through vivid guided memory before the maladaptive behaviors can be reset to something more beneficial to the person.  Also see Coherence Therapy for what is happening in the field of psychology along those lines.

I would imagine "learned helplessness" is only one of a general class of what may be called "achievement disorders" or "achievement delusions". This class of "disorders" (whether really psychologically formal diagnoses or not) are disorders or delusions affecting the concept of what it takes to get something, putting it at variance with the actual reality. Another one may be that you think you can get something, but you have to resort to morally corrupt or turpid means to get it when that may not be the case. Thus youth in gangs, thus corporate greed and corruption. (In some cases at least.) To some extent the current practice of capitalism(*). They feel there is no other way to get what they need or that it will get them more if they run over others in their pursuit of it.

(*) (Capitalism, if simply defined as the practice of enterprise and profit, is not necessarily bad -- the bad comes when this disorder supervenes upon it and the profit is placed above ethical duties. In bad capitalism, if you have two options, one of which is the ethically best and another slightly unethical but makes somewhat more profit, the latter will win. And this opens the door to the escalation of evil because once you convince yourself a little evil is okay, you start to become comfortable with doing a little more. And then a little more, and so on and so on and next thing you know you're yet another corrupt sleaze businessman. A little Donald Trump.)

Be wary of "achievement disorders/delusions". At the least they can waste your life. At the worst they can waste your soul.

Regarding the comment at 4:40 — "Does our school system promote learned helplessness?" Derek answers himself with, "I think to a certain degree we are doing that…"

NO.

Learned helplessness is the sine qua non of the majority of public ( and many private ) schools' existence. Sit where we tell you. Talk only when requested. Do arcane and pointless activities ad nauseum — or suffer immediate and sometimes physically painful negative consequences. Many, many people grew up in the stifling environment of the schools imposing conformity, to the exclusion of every other purpose, including education.

It is not "to a certain degree…", — it is the very lifeblood of the vast majority of education, from pre-K to graduate school — to enforce mindless obedience to the whims of "authority." This mindset is reinforced in many home environments, and certainly is promulgated in just about every single workplace. "Do what you're told!" "Don't talk back!" "My way or the Highway!"

This is not conducive to engendering critical thinking skills, independent reasoning and self-reliance. Is it any wonder, then, that people are meekly acquiescent to corruption and malfeasance in our governments and global corporations, plaintively bleating, "There's nothing we can do to change things."

This is why so many succumb to blatantly false "Conspiracy Theories" and internet rumors and hoaxes. I suppose it is "learned helplessness" on my part that I can see no reasonable path to reverse this deplorable situation.

I got a lot out of Martin Seligman's book, "Learned Optimism." He breaks the learned helplessness into three ways we may be thinking of our problems:
Personally: ["The problem here is me."]
Pervasively: ["The problem is affecting all aspects of my life."]
Permanently: ["This is never going to end."]
I'm trying to read it again. In the mean-time, I try to go through the day concentrating on just one of those three for now; trying to ferret-out subtleties in my thinking that I may be able to catch, challenge, & change.

I am immediately skeptical about the "distracting noise" experiment. There is a much simpler explanation of why people who could turn off the noise (but didn't) performed better: Those were the people who can concentrate better despite interference. Those who can't concentrate when there's a noise did turn it off. Therefore, in the group with no power to stop it, there were people who were and were not able to concentrate properly, while in the group with unexercised power, there were only people who didn't mind. Occam's razor.

The purpose of bureaucracy is to constantly nibble away at your self esteem and sanity until you come to believe you are indeed powerless.  The how is often complicated and obscure, but the why is obvious; in order for a governing body to govern autonomously, it must be a great deal more powerful than you. On Vsauce Michael talked about how certain societal constructs exist and operate fundamentally because of a common belief in their existence.  "The Tinkerbell Effect".  Helplessness can be learned in any number of ways, but in the case of the education system, helplessness is taught and enforced specifically to interfere with any goals that may conflict with the goals of the state.  School is probably the first and most severe experience most of us have with genuine loss of control, but it is usually not the last.

So the dogs needed to be helped in order to unlearn helplessness, but you think a pretentious video on the internet is enough to fix it in humans?

Telling people that more self confidence or self efficacy would make their lives easier is meaningless. You might as well be telling someone with anger management issues to calm down, or someone with depression to cheer up, or someone with a crippling phobia to just relax. It doesn't matter that you're technically correct, you're just stating the "what" while completely overlooking the "how."

It's the social equivalent of telling a scientist that we could explore the galaxy if we just had a hyper drive. It's a meaningless observation unless you have a suggestion for HOW you're going to build said hyper drive. And a motivational video on the internet is about as likely to solve either problem.

Learned helplessness is something that has to be unlearned over time, on an individual basis, whether you like it or not.

The "learned helplessness" or "employee mentality" is generally not 'learned' as much as it is 'enforced.'  Employee mentality is exactly what the vast majority of employers want from their employees.  I am now 58.  Earlier in my life I was one of those who would make a decision, rather than going to "the boss" for guidance.  All in all it worked out.  I tended to move upward in managerial position; however, I was just as likely to be reprimanded for exceeding my authority.  There is a risk-benefit analysis to do when you take initiative.  For me, when I was single and had few responsibilities and minimal economic needs the risk was small and the rewards probably exceeded the risks.  I'm not sure that most 'employees' today could take the same risks.  For Mr. Mueller a 1% chance at $1,000,000 is twice as good as $5,000 in the hand, because losing $5K will not affect him.  He could take that risk; most of us could not.  For most people the risk of losing $5k is far greater than a 1% potential of gaining $1M.  This is the fundamental problem that "successful" (read rich) people can not comprehend.  They see it as "helplessness" or an aversion to risk.  That is wrong, but you can't blame them for not understanding; they don't have the perspective to see the forest for the trees.

I get that it takes the drive - but that's the problem with our system as-is [and learned helplessness in general]. By setting a up our economy as a 'it's yours for the taking, you just have to go take it' system, you end up with outliers on both ends - the logical conclusion is, of course, greed and corruption, but the other end - the end which has learned helplessness - might just not have that drive. Or they may aspire to less. Should that be punished? We've cultivated a system where very few have opportunities handed to them to get ahead and the rest of us have to fight tooth and nail for it - and personally, I'm tired of it. My career field (AutoCAD tech in Florida) went south three times now - first with the housing bubble, then when it hit commercial work and then after I moved into military contracting... I can't even get an interview anymore because, despite a certification from a 2-year technical school and 5 years' experience, I don't hold a degree in my field. I came from a broken home and college just wasn't on the table for me despite my intelligence and amazing test scores. But more than that, if I had a degree I'd be en engineer, period. There is no reason whatsoever to have a degree for AutoCAD work. It's an unreasonable requirement. So... I've learned that I'm helpless in the face of a world that expects more of me than I am capable of giving.

Not to be rude, but this is as pointless a platitude as a suicide help line telling you that 'things get better' and 'you have every reason to live'. It's not just that people can't or wont' give actual, tangible help - it's that we're taught that no one owes us it. It's wrong to ask. We have to earn our own way. And so we sit alone, helpless.

I do think that school incorporates a kind of learned helplessness. In addition to Derek's argument about students defaulting to the advice of their superiors (i.e. managers, teachers) I feel that school does it to a greater extent. Many teachers encourage students to ask questions whenever they are confused about something, and many students I know capitalize on or even abuse that system. Practically, why would you do the work yourself when there's a knowledgable person who can already tell you all the answers with less effort on your part? ( I know that, logically, doing it yourself is a much better way of learning in the long-term, but I'm referring to short-term gain). As a result, students learn to trust their own logic less than that of their teachers', and thus are influenced to learned helplessness.

Perhaps I'm biased, since I am still in school. But my opinion is just that-- an opinion. I'm not saying it's fact.

I now show this to all my students every year (which has only been twice so far obviously) when I'm explaining how my chemistry and physics courses are going to be taught. When I teach it is all student driven. They are the ones doing the labs and then having discussions on what the labs mean. From their data they derive the physics equations or the chemical principles to construct a model of matter.  They will then use this model to further explore physics and chemistry and apply it to new scenarios to further develop or change the model. My hope is by giving them this push they will be able to finally break out of their learned helplessness. I don't give answers, I guide their arrival at the correct answers.  Students push back at first and don't really like it but by the end they are empowered and don't really need me anymore.  I just give them the equipment and they do the rest themselves.

So what I'm trying to say is thank you so much Derek for putting together this great video which helps me seed a conversation with my students on learned helplessness and how to empower themselves by learning how to learn.

How does learned helplessness compliment the illusion of control.  They're opposite problems and can both be harmful.  For example, gamblers may have an illusion of control in thinking that they can change the outcomes of certain games when they're really just throwing their money away.

Learned helplessness in the dogs experiment occurred when the subjects surrendered their illusion of control and realized that they needed help to get away from the pain and that there was nothing they could do to change it.  When the experiments created a way the subjects could escape, the dogs continued to believe that they were helpless until the experimenters held their paws and walked them through.

How do we know when situations can change in a way that allows us to influence them, and how do we know when said situations are casinos where we will likely always lose and should give up?

Psych babble will cease to be psycho babble once the same ideas expressed are available to others in one unified source that has been tested on subjects struggling to straighten out there lives.  The human mind can collect digest and express this babble found in the textbook in a unified believable way.   Ben Franklin tried something like this--but all he did was assemble a collection of disparate precepts that were not easily digestible and tested on a focus group.  It would be nice wouldn't it if we had a psychology in a textbook where after people struggled to learn everything in it, their "psychology" actually improved.  But maybe we have a "learned helplessness" that this comprehensible collection of tested precepts will never materialize.

I'd certainly say that our schools are promoting learned helplessness. Or at least something similar.
In my public American school, I decided to take a break from Honors English and switch to regular classes for one year. I was surprised at a certain unspoken change that I saw. The "simpler" curriculum consisted of several assignments that told the stories of people who had a dream or aspiration and either failed to meet their goal or were discouraged from doing so by "thinking realistically." Every time I encountered a story like this, I would ask a friend who was still taking an Honors course if they had been assigned such a story or essay or whatever the case was. And every single time they said no.

I believe that our schools are discouraging students in less advanced classes from aiming high in their lives and settling for "what they can accomplish," even though a single human can accomplish anything with the drive to do so.

There is a flaw in the thinking though. It leads to problems where there are too many cooks. There are old sayings like: there are too many chiefs and not enough Indians (I'll grant the biases in that saying). This logic may make large projects, like building pyramids, impossible. What makes civilization possible is coordinating large numbers of people in very precise ways. To use another quote, there is the right way, the wrong way and the army way. Do it the army way.

Before my psychology teacher went over the chapter on learned helplessness, he wrote a problem on the board. 

The problem was 5 words. Of those 5 words you were supposed to create another word of the same letters that the words originally had. He divided the class into 2 parts. Each part had a different set of words. He never told us what he was testing for, so  we were like "ok i don't see the point to this."

After we were done, he asked us how many of us actually did all 5 words, most of us said no. And he told us that this is what learned helplessness is. You know you can figure it out, but they just gave up and mentally said "oh i can't do it."

I really like most if not all of his videos, but for me this one was GOLD. Sincerely, thank you Derek, if you happen to read this!

P.S. It shows me that instictively I've been doing some right stuff all along, which I really found motivating. Other than that the video gave me one more perspective on my choice to drop out of architecture university to pursue a career in Games Design.
On top of that it introduced me to a concept I haven't thought of, which I believe has great potential application in games and their ludological structure.

Of course, dogs don't have the same mentality as people do, so any psychological studies on dogs don't directly apply to people. It's an intriguing theory, to be sure. It appears to even explain certain human behaviors. But in the end the substitution of species in the experiment invalidates it.

There's also the anecdote of the baby elephant that is chained to a stake. It struggles against the chain trying to free itself and finally gives up. Then, even as an adult it is easily confined by the same chain and stake that it could easily free itself from, but it doesn't try. This too is a form of learned helplessness. The trouble is, that story is only partially true. If you scare the adult elephant enough it will free itself from the inadequate chain and stake.

Good video, it was quite interesting to have this pointed out, I had noticed it myself before but hadn't taken much notice of it.

A few problems with the experiments. The dogs were taught they had no control of the shock. The fact they were given the power to turn off the switch was not even a factor. In that, they could not know they now had the option. The other dog's actions of, say, jumping over a fence would not be helpful because they do not know the other dogs shocker is being turned off, so they cannot learn from observing. The humans could have done worse on test simply because they were annoyed that they had no control, thusly occupying some of their cognitive actions.

Employees should ask their supervisor if they are unsure, because often moving forward in an improper direction can lead to loss of money due to time loss or breakage, and adding more wasted time for others down the road. Not trying to dispute the fact that people should think for themselves, but asking questions is a great way to learn on the job, and often goes underused as a tool.

Even though I have problems with the arguments, I do agree learned helplessness is real, and an issue for many of us.

They had to move the dogs, because they had to be trained to understand the cause and effect. As aforementioned, they had no way to learn that fact. They learned after the second time, which was the first chance to see a pattern.

Actually, this APPLIED to me, but I got myself out of it. Not the situation with the questions to the boss, but something similar in social issues.

I was not the most social kid on school, and most 'popular' kids were always talking behind my back and looking down on me. I learned this was normal while 17 of those years past.
I had 3 people in the 5th grade I could get along with a bit, but in they didn't pass the year. One of those friends didn't even say 'hi' back to me when I greeted him, for no reason at all. This hurted so much that I decided to change my life for good. I decided I would do everything to get more socially accepted and to get myself out of loneliness. 
Before you start yelling: "You should have stayed yourself!", I still am myself. I'm just not rude anymore, have got a sense of humour and wear more casual clothes.
How did I get there? 
I tried to talk as much and to as many people as possible (outside of school) and analysed myself and watched reactions on my stories or on the stories of others. I could see others clearly didn't like some of my comments, something I never noticed before. I saw laughing made people happier and everyone liked it to get a reaction on stories they told. I adjusted myself with those things and loads of other adjustments.

I have no regrets I have changed. I've got a nice group of friends since university and more importantly: I am not looked down on anymore.

comment_text:
Just a thought, why couldn't the humans be given shocks? I mean what is it about us that makes us so much better than dogs, supposedly? Shocks are a pretty strong distraction too. Or, here's a thought, why not take the shocks out altogether?

Sure, I know there are going to be two kinds of people commenting on this. The first will try and ridicule me by calling me overly sensitive and invoking some strange PETA equivalence. The other would say that we didn't know better back then and that we don't do those things now.

I'd just ask the first lot to grow up. To the second though, I'd point out that these experiments were conducted in the late 60s. That's not all that long ago. We haven't managed to substantially improve the lot of animals (domesticated or otherwise) a whole lot since then. It's only by stopping and thinking about these experiments can we try and mitigate the damage we may currently be doing and that we may inadvertently have cause in the foreseeable future.

There's no changing what happened. And animal testing is going to be around for some time now, at the least. We are trying to get around it, but it will take some time. But until then, we should probably think about what we're doing. We constantly hear people telling others to think before they say/do something that might hurt someone else. As scientists, we can probably do that with our animal testing experiments.

I know that there are committees in place in every lab and research facility that takes care of the animals being tested. And that system come into place because someone asked us to think twice about our actions and their impact on the animals. But we cannot forget that our actions have an impact on the lives of those animals nor can we simply blindly rely on the judgement of those on the committee. Safety (of the scientists and the test subjects) is a key concern that should be at the forefront of every individual's thought process.

1. A lot of kids probably felt that school was a punishment, but I never did. I enjoyed and still enjoy learning.

2. While I believe there you are correct about this phenomenon, I also believe that not every one who finds themselves feeling helpless is living an illusion. Some people are actually helpless.

Just consider the dogs at the start of the experiment. They had not learned to be helpless, they actually were.

3. This reminds me of many platitudes and memes that essentially tell the reader, "You aren't trying hard enough." and "You have low self esteem." "Just do it." Ignoring the systemic roadblocks that lay in the path of so many people.

Some of these roadblocks are being taught to feel helpless, but other roadblocks are racism, being born in a third world country, and even bad luck, just to name a few.

4. I don't want to get too into talking about myself, as I think there are many more people out there with much larger mountains in their path, than I have in mine. But I know me and my situation best.

I did go to film school. Attracted to it by my first love music (the film department contained all the Audio Production courses). I've been out of school since 2000 and have as of yet only had 2 jobs that relate to my degree. One of these jobs was teaching video production to kids in middle school and high school. This job actually made me feel good instead of feeling awful as I do at retail jobs. Anyway the point is, I only got that job because someone I went to school with knew I was looking for work.

So, to say "no one can help you," is silly. I didn't make that job happen through sheer will. It had to be available and I had to know the right person. That's how the world works, you know the right people and you're in the right place at the right time.

I mean you even say, "You have to demonstrate that you can do what you wanna do." I ask, to whom? To the person or people who can help make that possible. In your case, I'm guessing it was us, the viewers out here in youtube land.

5. Control is an illusion. No one has any control over anything at all. I think you're in a lot of trouble if you think you're the master of your future. I'm not saying things are written in stone, there's simply too many variables for you to just make something happen because you desire it, because you will it.

Well, unless you have a Green Lantern power ring. :P

6. Really what makes the best outcome for everyone is working together, helping each other. Someone helped you, whether you acknowledge this or not. No one does anything in a vacuum (except die), there are always other people involved.

That's why I try my best to encourage and help as I can, and why part of the reason I wish for success is all the people I care about that I for whom I could clear some road blocks out of the way.

7. I think this feels like a response to someone who wanted a leg up from you.

8. I think humans are smart enough to devise a society where there aren't roadblocks, where people can pursue there talents. A culture where ones limits are only the ones from within. Sadly, no one wants to work toward that, they all believe that society IS what it is and has been, that it's immutable.

Hm. I think perhaps the whole of human society has a case of Learned Helplessness. ;)

Say there was a person in a manufacturing facility. Using pneumatic nail guns, electric drills, industrial tools, things of that nature. Say further that he doesn't know how to do some task. So he takes @Veritasium 's advice and doesn't go and ask his supervisor for help. Several things can happen at this point:
1. He tries something without thinking and fails. He gets yelled at/threatened to be fired.
2. He tries something with thinking and fails. He thinks for a few minutes, to try and reason out how to do the task. The supervisor catches him seemingly staring off into space and yells at the employee/threatens to fire him.
3. After attempting to reason through how to do the task in the best way, he makes an attempt, not knowing what the hell he is doing, and shoots a nail into his hand, or damages whatever he is working on to the point where it needs to be replaced, or fails in some other way. He gets yelled at, or threatened to be fired.
Bottom line, I think @Veritasium has a profound disconnect with reality. I doubt he ever once worked at a real fast-paced work environment where the supervisor-employee connection is so vital and necessary to the learning process.

This is why excuses like "it's just a game" are nonsense.  Games are how we learn - and how we learn how to learn.  The most important thing about any game is player agency - or the lack thereof.  The player has no options in Snakes and Ladders, which is by design, because the game is about fatalism.  It's presented as competitive, but it is entirely automatic.  The game literally plays itself.  It was designed to teach children that sometimes, bad things happen and there's nothing you can do about it but keep moving forward.  Is that a good lesson?  It depends on the situation, and how the lesson is taught.  Is it being used to teach the child that they're helpless, that there's nothing they can do when things don't go their way - or is it being used to teach that things don't always have to go your way, that even when you fall you can keep forging ahead and not let it bother you?  An important element of the game's design is that there is no lose condition.  No matter what setbacks you have, you keep going until you reach the top.

Of course, the other side of the spectrum, the illusion of perfect control, can also be detrimental to your health. It could cause anxiety and a feeling of incompetence. 

The art is to identify where your actions have the most effect.

In order to break the cycle of learned helplessness, you must first start looking at the positives in life rather than focusing on the negatives. From there you will grow to be successful in whatever you endeavour to do. You would think that a bed bound, Secondary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis sufferer would devolve into helpless despair, but instead, I see this condition as a way to help others learn to adapt to their new found disabilities (although I prefer to call it an Adaptability). In the past 5 years I have learned, on my own, how to navigate my way through the Australian Health System to gain care for myself. I live alone and have carers come in 4 times a day. I also help others to learn how to become more independent despite their limitations. I have peg baskets hanging off the side of my bed holding items I use daily. On the other side I have a bucket hanging off the bed railing with bottles of water so I can drink when I have no one here. There are all kinds of ways to become self sufficient even when it's quite difficult. I have learned how to find different agencies and funding bodies to help other people gain equipment they sorely need to lead as normal a life as possible. 

The point is, though my body is physically incapable of doing a heck of a lot of things that able bodied people take for granted, it has, in no way, stopped my mind from working to figure out how to make my life easier and enable me to live alone and without full time care. For a while, I was in very real danger of becoming another statistic of young people living in nursing homes. That is still a danger I face every day, but it will never stop me from looking on the bright side and helping others who need the help.

One problem with the complaint about learned helplessness and blaming schools for it is that if we say that, we're acting like everyone's goals are good goals and positive for society. Children are often megalomaniacal if allowed. If a child is disruptive in class and you can't figure out what else to do in a reasonable amount of time, you must crush their will to prevent them from stealing away everyone else's time/attention/education/life. It just is not that easy to do everything for everyone all the time. In fact, nothing at all resembling that will ever happen. So, yes I believe there is a good answer to the problem, but it will not be simple or easy. And some people will just always be a problem and never be fixed.

Reminds me of a story I once heard of a man who traveled to India. As the man was passing the elephants, he suddenly stopped, confused by the fact that these huge creatures were being held by only a small rope tied to their front leg. No chains, no cages. It was obvious that the elephants could, at anytime, break away from their bonds but for some reason, they did not.

He saw a trainer nearby and asked why these animals just stood there and made no attempt to get away. “Well,” the trainer said, “when they are very young and much smaller we use the same size rope to tie them and, at that age, it’s enough to hold them. As they grow up, they are conditioned to believe they cannot break away. They believe the rope can still hold them, so they never try to break free.”

The man was amazed. These animals could at any time break free from their bonds but because they believed they couldn't, they were stuck right where they were. Like the elephants, how many of us go through life hanging onto a belief that we cannot do something, simply because we failed at it once before?

This reminds me of a concept I heard about from Ze Frank, first articulated by Jung, that of the provisional life. We think about the goal we want to accomplish, and we think, once I finish this section of my life, I'll be liberated to do the thing I want to do, to achieve that big fantasy I have. Once I finish high school, I can work on my novel. Once I finish college, I'll have time to learn Mandarin Once I earn enough from this temp job I start learning how to program. And all of these things will be amazing and I'll look amazing doing it. I will achieve so much, once all this is out of the way.

Naturally, the belief that something will be achieved later means it's never started now. Learned helplessness is not merely giving in to the despair of a scenario, it's believing that the scenario is the only way of being, followed by a reward at its inevitable end. We're more comfortable believing that than we are accepting that we're making excuses. If we make excuses we can avoid failure. It's self-defense, nothing more. 

All I can say is that as a 20 year old who's finished the second draft of a novel started four years ago, and eagerly looking forward to a (hopefully) final and frenetic summer of rewriting, hard work is best started now. Whatever it is, now.

I completely agree with the science and sentiment in this video, but it sounds like you were searching for a mentor in the film producer and that is not necessarily a symptom of learned helplessness. All of the greatest minds and achievers in the world, in addition to being self-starters, searched for and eventually benefitted from the wisdom of their mentors - Plato had Socrates, Warren Buffet had Benjamin Graham, Mark Zuckerberg had Steve Jobs, etc. In this video, Tim Ferriss serves as your mentor by introducing the concept of learned helplessness.

Some potential mentors are more receptive than others, so as long as we don't completely rely on the permission or validation of others to take action, a mentor(s) can be a huge benefit to us because they can shorten the learning curve in our fields of interest.

I started with resumes and emails but after that I made a list of every Game Studio in New York and visited them in person to drop of my reel and resume. Do not listen to this crap. If helplessness can be self-taught, it follows that it can be taught inadvertently and everyone knows that that's impossible. Poor people are that way because they are victims of circumstance, not because the welfare state has taught them that they are. If you want to improve the lot of the poor, remember that any difference between people is a reason to hate. Envy is not a sin as long there is inequality. Only through hate of those who have achieved much, is there any hope of your improvement. And the method for that improvement is political. You must increase your numbers to use majority rule to capture the monopoly on the legal use of force; not the indifferent free market which only rewards those who have the most appreciative customers.

In order for school to not be punishment, it must be voluntary, which would also accelerate the interest of the children, as they would be able to pick the fields in which they are most intrigued.  When you force people to do something, they will scarcely be motivated to actually accomplish the task.

When you're told it's not possible, a basic human drive to prove you wrong comes into play.  This is the heart of the taunting of the black and white philosophy.  I don't necessarily agree with it, because it is terribly brutal sometimes, but it undeniably works usually.

This is used to train elephants in a circus.  How do you keep such a strong animal from running away and overpowering it's trainers?  When elephants are young, their trainers chain one of the elephant's ankles to something secure to keep them from running away.  As they grow up, just feeling something on their ankle makes them think they can't break free even if it's connected to something no stronger than a tent spike.

I completely agree.. School was made to teach kids the things they needed to work the factory job of the industrial age.. In a factory your questions and thoughts are meaningless, you simply hafto do the same thing over and over again, until you go home.. The educational system has not changed since then, and still teaches kids to be obediant workers, who dont think for themselves but rather learns to do a task in their sleep. 
For people who know how things work behind the task, or understand how thinks are as they are, but suffer on doing the task or find it boring, school is torment, because the teachers dont know anything besides the content of a book they are quoting. As a programmer, you go to a good programming school, where you learn the basics, like the language and general thought process of making software. but when you are done with the school you know just enough to make a "hello world" website or app, not anywhere near enough to make complex software, games or websites. The rest is up to you.. I learned by making a clone of an old Warlords game from the 90's. This lead to bigger projects and finally i found a job, where i was confronted with even more challenging tasks, that required me to learn 5 new programming languages and tools to perform daily tasks.. With enough effort i am now a vital part of this company.. But i started out as a novice, after 6 years of programming school and a bathelor degree in computer science.. :) the annoying thing is that a collegue dropped out of school 2 years earlier, never visited a programming school, but instead self learned it all, and he has equal if not slightly better skills than i do.. 
School is not worth spending all your life on.. Find out what you love to do, early, find out what minimal school time you need to reach a stage of understanding and "papers" to do what you want to do, and then self experience the rest of the way.. the internet makes this much easier, with the help of veritasium and similar youtube channels that teach things on a "why does it work like this" basis, rather than "To finish this task, do these 5 steps" :)

So some friends and I in Vancouver have a fake holiday that we've celebrated now for maybe 3-4 years. It's called St. Project's Day.

Every autumn when the weather starts to get grey and rainy, each person adopts a secret project on their own and works on it throughout the duration of the winter. The project has to be something new to you, something that exposes you to a bit of the unexplored.

Come spring (early May perhaps?) when the weather is finally nice enough to have a beach picnic, we share a meal with food and drink, and we present to each other the results of our efforts. Two years ago I picked up French after failing it in grade 9 (I'm reasonably conversant now!). This year's project was yoga (I can finally touch my toes without issue!).

I think St. Project's Day is relevant to this video as it's a yearly exercise in trying the things we don't know how to do, striking out on your own and struggling through the "I can't do this" moments.

My Learned Helplessness came from the home and the schools. Constantly told that I could do anything I wanted, but then penalized for not doing something "their way" or "perfect enough". Discouraging remarks from my parents that I'll "never amount to anything."

As much as I would like your message to be true, it's nearly impossible for those to have learned helplessness to overcome it, just like those dogs who had to be PHYSICALLY MOVED, and more than once, to finally realize that there was an answer. When you're entrenched in learned helplessness, you're running in circles, with no idea that the cage is actually open.

It takes outside help, be it therapy, or like my case, being homeless for 2 1/2 years. I still deal with uncertainty about my path in life, but through some of the hardest hardships, I've been able to eek my way out of the cage somewhat. I still go back, because despite the nature of it, I still have a semblance of safety associated with it...such is the nature of learned helplessness.

Only if things continue to go well for me will I be able to fully overcome this "programming" that lasted for more than 18 years of my life (I'm 33 now). Fortunately, I'm more receptive to constructive criticism and more likely to process it in a positive manner. I also give a damn far less often than I have in the past, and this has had a surprisingly positive outcome.

Just gotta keep trucking. <--- And a year or two ago, I would never have thought I could say that.

I think bringing a problem to your boss has more to do with absolving guilt and getting confirmation about the difficulty of your problem. If it takes you too long to fix something that's broken, you're likely to be reprimanded for it. But if your boss is involved, or at least informed of the problem and can't provide their own solution, you can avoid being scolded. Likewise, if your boss is also stumped by the problem, it's not the result of your incompetence. In that sense, it's a great example of the fundamental attribution error: if I can't solve the problem, it's because it's difficult; if you can't solve the problem, it's because you're stupid.

As a self-employed person who truly enjoys his career, I really enjoyed this video.  I remind myself every day that it's always up to me to make things happen, even — and especially — when those things feel impossible.

I'm still in high school, and you're right more than you think you are. school's aren't about teaching us how to survive in the real world as they claim. no, they're about making helpless little robots to serve the corporate giant (OK, maybe a bit of an exaggerated metaphor there but you get the point). I'm guilty of this as you. I try and try hard to figure things out on my own, but I've been trained from such a young age to rely on the teachers that I've forgotten how to help myself outside of the house to an extent. It's saddening and it's one of the (many) things that bugs me about our education system. No longer is it about learning how to make your way through life independently as was the original American dream for education; no, it's about training us to "use teamwork" to solve problems that can very easily be solved on our own. I'm not shooting down teamwork, but in the case of a school system and in a lot of every day situations it's not needed. People are completely capable of solving their own problems.

The way I look at it is, every problem has a solution. If you find yourself complaining about something, or feeling negatively about a certain situation, then you know "the problem". Next step, think of a solution and act on it. The more difficult the solution, the more satisfying and enriching it is to compete, I find.

About school, the senseless punishments we endure is called math class: we're left to assume that math is simply a game we play to be good at the next math class. After the useful +-x/, things rapidly become very hard to justify "teaching". Our brains determine the value of that "education" by dumping those memories as soon as we leave the room. And can any of us use the higher math when given the opportunity? I doubt there are many who even know where it can be used. So-called "applications" in our math books include nonsensical, absurd, or even impossible circumstances that have nothing to do with real life, which is great evidence to anyone's brain that "higher math" has no use at all. Electric shocks to our feet, every day. Of course, if math professors weren't the ones to decide on math books, and authors of math books were actually held to a worthwhile educational standard where "applications" are scrutinized instead of being treated as unimportant, math class could finally get a good reputation.

I learned about the serenity prayer from Kurt Vonnegut's Slaughterhouse V in high school, when I was even more arrogant and willful than now. It was an incredibly uncomfortable sentence that stuck with me for the last 7 years, and I never stopped wrestling it on a weekly basis. It was hate at first sight, because until that moment, I was so sure that I would enjoy a prosperous future thanks to what I perceived to be an above-average intelligence allowing me to shape my own fate.

I could never dismiss the line, though, because it planted the seed of doubt. "And the wisdom to know the difference" needled the back of my head, and caused me to question my convictions. "How can I be so sure I'm going to be fine?" "I guess there are some things that I can't change, but that's for like, technical things, like being able to fly by flapping my arms." "People can manipulate their world including other people, it's just not practical to rely on it, that's probably what it means." There was no way to dismiss the doubt, and its jagged pain as I turned the phrase over and over in my head smoothed out into a dull soreness.

So even though my age increased, my happiness had not, and I started to internalize its lesson. "I am not nearly in control of my world as I thought I would be. I was a dumb teenage jerk to think otherwise." I consider some aspects of it to be good. I learned humility, and I'm no longer quick to throw stones because I know the construction of my house. But it hurts, and it's a struggle to be serene when your personality deep down still rages for change.

I'm glad you caution against the advice of this phrase. It's validating and vindicating to hear someone present helplessness as a learned behavior, and it's enough to make me try again.

This is where history and education are so crucial. Not having to deal with learned helplessness and/or having the opportunity to overcome it are such huge privileges in today's society. If you were trained in or put into a situation like the first group of dogs where you really have absolutely no control, it's easy, even logical, to get discouraged and to give up trying to change the situation. When the situation finally changes, whether it's with or without you knowing, your internal biases continue to function, and that'll usually dictate how you react to the situation. In the real world, this often results in self-fulfilling prophecies of the successful becoming more successful and the historically oppressed remaining stuck at the bottom. 

I really have mixed feelings about it all. On the one hand, telling people that they'll always have opportunities and that they have complete control over their lives often comes from a place of unfounded or narrowly situational optimism that ignores personal histories and really valid reasons for being stuck in terrible situations. On the other hand, a lack of optimism may result in missing opportunities to get out of those situations, further reinforcing them. 

"So find some sort of balance between the two extremes!" may be the answer, though really, many people don't have the patience to put in the work for this from either side. And so the world goes on...

I can't really agree with the idea that only we can help ourselves. Indeed, it contradicts what you were talking about previously.

Dogs conditioned to learned helplessness needed their handlers to show them how to escape. Incentives were ineffective. If we are to say this is analogous to human behavior, which is the point I believe you were trying to make, then simply telling people to go out and do it because good things could happen is completely ineffective. 

When you were applying to acting and film schools, or calling upon that filmmaker, you weren't seeking others to do things for you, you were looking for someone to give you a chance to do it for yourself! Comparing the pursuit of education and skills to attempts at hand-outs is not just incorrect, but detrimental to others.

It's up to those with influence to give chances to those who don't; no one is an island.

@Veritasium Hello Veritasium, my name is Jonathan! I just wanted to thank you so much for this video! You see I have Learned Helplessness, I just didn't know it until now. When I was 3 years old I was diagnosed with JRA, or Juvenile Rheumatoid Idiopathic Systemic Arthritis ( I know its a mouthful) At the time there was no direct treatment for my illness, they could only prescribe me Prednisone, also known as Steroids (not the ones that make you buff xD ) because doctors hadn't created any bio drugs yet for my illness. I was forced to take massive doses of these "Steroids" to keep my illness at bay. But the side-effects were much worse. Not only did I retain water and become super chubby, but the medicine had a hidden side effect, which when taking massive doses like I was, led to you developing Osteoporosis/Necrosis. Basically the veins and capillaries feeding the bones in my joins began to die off, meaning my bones were dieing, and crumbling. My hip ball joint was the first to go, it crumbled and resulted in me becoming wheelchair bound. I was told to do physical therapy to keep my Arthritis at bay during this time, but at that young age of 6 I wasn't strong enough to push myself past the pain. It ended up that my hips had healed and I was ready to walk again thanks to a new drug just developed called "Enbrel" taking my off the horrid Prednisone. The only problem was after about 3 years of being in a wheelchair, without much physical therapy, my legs and ankles were permanently frozen in a sitting position, and my hands were stuck in almost permanent fists (due to the way I slept at night with my hands closed). Meaning that even though I could now walk, my legs were locked up, not allowing me to. Many doctors over the years have told me that it is irreparable, and I will be stuck in a wheelchair my entire life. (heck, the first doctor that diagnosed me and put me in a wheelchair a few days after my birthday said "Well kid... sell the bike you got for your birthday... you're never walking again...") After years of my mother and my family pushing me to try anyway, and actually gaining some progress including assisted walking for a few steps, I gave up. I accepted it as unchangeable, inevitability in my life,  I would never be able to walk, to play soccer, to run outside with my little sisters, anything like that ever again. And because of this mentality I have been stuck. With the wheelchair I have needed endless help to do anything, get drinks, go to the bathroom, bath, eat, everything. And due to this I began relying on other people to get me what I needed, and where I wanted to go. For years I have had dreams and aspirations to do great things, but they have gone nowhere due to the way I approached them, I would find someone doing said dream, and beg them to get me in on it, to allow me to skip the work to get there, to pity me and my situation. I am turning 21 in 2 days. I will be a full blown adult, and I have nothing to show for it. No job, no schooling, no home of my own, no girlfriend or fiance like my older sister, nothing. And on top of everything my illness slowed down my aging somewhat, so I look and sound about 12~13 years old. I always told myself "Who would hire (or love) a kid in a wheelchair, who cannot do anything but draw art, can not lift heavy things, can not do anything for himself, and looks and sounds like a child." But your video has really helped me realise this mindset. I wanted to thank you, because on my 21st birthday I'm going to try again, on everything. I'm going to try therapy, and see if I can walk, I'm going to try and find something I love, and make my way to it without help, I'm going to change my life for the better, without reliance on others to do the heavy lifting for me! Thank you so much for opening my eyes and giving me a second chance. I love your channel and everything you do on it. You are amazing! Once again I thank you, I cannot thank you enough!

Sincerely,
-Jonathan

I was always told i was smart. I had great deductive reasoning skills. But i was also told I was horrible at math. Time and time again I would fail. It got to the point where not only did I hate math but I literally was afraid of it. It made me question my intelligence and was a huge blow to my self esteem. It got so bad i would have panic attacks in class and even passed out during an exam. When I got to college I was placed in one of the lowest math classes on campus. The system had decided that i was destined to not learn the language of science and a whole world (I would argue The world) would be closed off to me. I decided otherwise. I worked my butt off faced my fears passed 11 college math classes (literally there isn't a math class at my junior college I have not taken and passed) and I am now going on to university majoring in mechanical engineering. It was the least likely path to this career and despite literally being told I could not do it after being told I was just not "math minded" that I would fail and was a failure I pushed back found a way and am now succeeding. I hope my story and Derek's video will help others to find their way to what they want even if it isn't the typical path. That employee mentality is a logical result of two factors. One, you need to cooperate with the team and your boss is there to set up priorities. And two, you always need your boss to know you're busy and what are you doing. The best you can do is to come with "hey boss, I'm done with that task, what about I start doing this task now?". It might happen that your boss will just tell you that's okay. But plenty of times he'll tell you to do something with higher priority instead. If you didn't pick a new task beforehand, you might think you just rely on your boss with things you knew about but if you come with your choice first, only then you realize how often was your intuition wrong.

The best practical steps you can take to counter learned helplessness is to make sure you get a prototype up and running then edit that prototype. It's more important that you get something barely functional out the door so you don't have time to learn helplessness.  A good example would be buying a used camera and start creating films and content instead of waiting for others to teach you how to work on film.

The only danger with assuming that you can achieve more than you think you can is it can also lead to learned helplessness. Imagine wanting to be a doctor and the only way you can be functional is to have 8 hours of sleep each day.  You get to the stage where you have to start practicing being a doctor and they are expecting you to run on 5 hours sleep. As your ideal and limitations conflict with one another, they put you in a situation you really can't handle. It would be really easy to think if I just trust that I can do it then I will be a doctor instead of choosing a better option still in the medical field. This is like the dog just taking shocks instead of just jumping out of the way to a much better option.

This is the message I've been trying to tell people for years, that people can accomplish their dreams, they just have to believe they can do it. When I was in 6th grade I wanted to become a physicist. I read books about it, I watch specials, and I loved looking for the reasons the universe exist. I drew diagrams, created logic problems in my head, and began to find an understanding of the universe, but what I didn't know was that science is a world of proving not listening, and anytime I had an idea of what the world might be, I needed the math or no one would listen, the math that I wouldn't be able to express with out years of work and effort, even though I understood the grand concepts of it, so I gave up on it. Now I won't admit I knew exactly how all the laws worked like I was a child prodigy, because if I did, someone here would of probably heard of me and I probably would of kept at it, but all I wanted at that time was someone to help support me, and help me understand and explain my ideas. What I would want now looking back at it, was someone to express to me that I was in control of my own life, and that sometimes all these AP classes that I couldn't handle wouldn't be the end of my life if I didn't take them and didn't get into a good college, to tell me the path isn't so ridged and that my life wouldn't turn to complete waste if I fell off it. 

Funny thing though, like you, I taken the route to become a filmer (not a word, but cinematographer sounded like a bit much as a title). I knew it would be tough, but I knew I could do it completely independently. I've learned video editing, image editing and website development all at my finger tips. Though incidentally, I'm finding I'm looking for that help again, that person to do film projects with, halting my work because I make the excuse to myself that I can't do this with out another person, I guess this video is just a sign to move on.

So anyone reading this, I just want you to know you have so much prosthetic knowledge with technology these days, you just got to reach out and access it. You can do whatever you dream to, and you can do it your way.

Another good example of Learned Helplessness comes from the working Elephants in places like India. When they are young they are tied up leash made with a piece of rope that is quite capable of restraining a young elephant. They quickly learn that when they are thus tied up they are stuck. By adulthood they don't even try to break the same leash despite the fact that the rope isn't even vaguely adequate anymore - it's just ingrained in them that they can't do it.

There are some major caveats and issues with this way of thinking that very much need to be addressed here.

But, before I start, please note that I am not in any way claiming that learned helplessness is not a thing or that the research into it is flawed.

It strikes me that the way of thinking presented in this video is very common among the wealthiest and most powerful - and most privileged - people in our society.  It dovetails very well with the general meritocratic ideal that the most successful people are the most talented and have earned their privileged place.  This way of thinking, though, has the knock-on effect that people who follow it also tend to conclude that those who have not been successful simply aren't trying hard enough.  It frames social status as a reflection of character.

The problems with this are twofold.  First, it ignores the role that external factors play in determining which people and which ventures are successful.  In this sense, it is necessary to be willing to try things in order to succeed; but, it is not sufficient.  This is particularly insidious because the people who are in the best position to have their stories heard are also those for whom chance factors have worked out the best, leading to a sort of confirmation bias.

Even worse, though, this sort of thinking tends to lead to people dismissing the identification of structural inequities that contribute to the perpetuation of the various sorts of inequality - racial, gendered, etc. - that are already endemic to society.  It's why we hear (even in comments on this very video) that, for instance, feminists are just whining and want everything handed to them without having to work for it.  The problem with that is that there is quite a bit of research showing that this sort of "just go for it" attitude is generically better received when coming from men than from women (or from white people than black people, etc.).

To use a more dramatic example, when white people dismiss discussion of police violence against black people by saying things like "well, if they just obeyed the police, this wouldn't happen," they're defaulting to assuming that the movement against these incidents is a manifestation of a sort of learned helplessness rather than a response to a real injustice manifesting from a real bias in the legal system.

Or to put it another way, sometimes learned helplessness is just the visible manifestation of social structures that create actual helplessness.

I love material like this because I think this kind of education is more universally beneficial and indeed needed than any one specific physics example (even though I love physics!).

But I would press you further on your content. You said yourself that the dogs could indeed be trained out of learned helplessness, even if only very specific methods of treatment worked. But then to advocate that there is no helping people other than them helping themselves out of their own situation is an unfortunately confusing and in-congruent message. (We recognize you yourself are trying to help by making this video.) More likely, an effective method for treating people out of learned helplessness has not yet been understood, but probably worse is to conclude that there is no method, or that because it is a journey everyone must do on their own that no assistance is possible. As with the dogs, we need to find the way to move people out of the shocks, so people can do it for themselves later.

But to clarify and agree with you insofar, what I mean is not that we should be doing more to help people get into acting or directing school directly, but to help people believe that they can find a way to make their goals reality, rather than not try. There should be a way to help, but this is about helping people more fundamentally with their outlook, rather than their goals directly. Teach a man to fish rather than give a man a fish, and all that. Hopefully you understand my distinction.
