I think schools and especially universities instil a sort of institutionalized way of thinking: "you have to have formal training in order to do something! without formal training you are just a hobbiest at best!"

In my community college the focus was completely the other way around. We were told to solve our problems ourselves. We had the knowledge and the tools so we should arrive to a solution. Often it wasn't the perfect solution -- which makes sense because as a student your reference frame is limited so you have no idea what is "perfect or neat or production wise solution" but it was a solution.
And we were always pushed to analyse what we could do different next time to get a better result.

So I never went to my manager saying I didn't know something -- often my managers knew less about technology and engineering than we did.

But I did learn over time that when you are stuck and start to brute force trouble shoot a problem that it is wise to ask someone else. Even an intern, who can actually ask things when you explain the problem that switches the lever and you can back the train up and proceed on a different train of thought.

The thing about learned helplessness in the workplace is the following:
If I make a mistake, my boss (let´s call him "P") is going to take the blame for it. It´s how it works: "Hey P, why did Jeremy do X? That wouldn´t have happened had you instructed him correctly, therefore you´re at least partly to blame for X happening!"
P essentially carries the responsibility that all his underlings stay mistake-free.

And if he carries the responsibility, I would be an asshole if I didn´t consult him before doing anything ambiguous, even though I know what to do. It´s his ass on the line as well as mine, so he HAS to get the final say on what I do!
If he isn´t there, or there is a heat-of-the-moment decision to make, you can bet your ass that I´m going to make it myself, but that doesn´t mean that I wouldn´t communicate or consult with him whenever necessary and possible.

Am I helpless in this? I don´t feel that way. Is it helplessness by choice? Maybe. But i don´t feel like it devalues me in my worth as either employee or person.

With regards to education, home situations play a large part of what a student brings to the classroom. Some students have developed learned helplessness from their parents, siblings etc. Others have developed it from previous years in school. 
Teachers are absolutely aware of it. I know, I've got my certificate. There are strategies in the hands of teachers to help overcome this. 
The first thing is trying to help students achieve something called a growth mindset. It essentially refers to what you were saying; That overcoming obstacles and challenges rests in their hands. 
Is education a form of control? Yes. It is. But in all honesty students do have the ability to dictate their situations. I try to help my students see that their actions are the reason they get where they are. Their choices are the sole reason for the positive and negative responses they receive. Self regulation plays a large role in a student's intellectual development.

Yes, to a certain extent, attendees (such as children) of any school are taught there are certain things beyond their control.  By this I mean, I learned in a General Psychology elective college class (and I can't remember if there is a term for it) that virtually all institutions require its members/inhabitants to give up choice and individuality for the collective benefit of the running of the institution.  An example given in class of this would be hospitals; individual patients do not decide when mealtime is, the hospital decides for them so that staff responsible for feeding can just go from room to room instead of responding to individual patients' requests.  So applying this to schools, the whole idea of a class means, for gains in efficiencies, a group of people all get together for learning some subject.  The opposite would be totally individual instruction (commonly called tutoring :-) ).

My job involves working closely with students, ranging in ages 4 - 18, and building skills in independent learning, work ethic, and elementary -  secondary school Math and English.  The issue of learned helplessness is the defining factor between students who are able to rise to success in our program to those who simply stagnant, and eventually drop out.  Honestly, the major player in children adopting this immobilizing mentality are often times stemmed from their parents or prominent adult figures in their life; lack of scheduling or keeping to deadlines in your personal life, deflecting responsibility (even over the smallest of instances), and most other key tendencies in learn helplessness that the providers, display and are often passively taught to their little ones.  In children, within an academic context, I end up hearing the most ridiculous excuses from students (mostly between the elementary to middle school years - since teens are "too cool" for talking.):
- "I couldn't finish my homework because I have a lot of work" grade 1 student
- "I've just been so busy with the holidays coming up" grade 3 student
- "I tried to do the work, but my mom said it's ok if I just do 1 page [instead of the assigned 5]"

But the absolute worst is:
- "My (parent / guardian) said I don't have to [because of an illegitimate reason]"

Now obviously, most 3rd graders are not responsible for holiday preparations (Although I don't want to be entirely dismissive towards the ones who do.), or a 1st grade student isn't overcome by projects assigned at school; these are learnt excuses, by-products, of the BS adults spout.  But what I find most discouraging in character and independence building in children is when parents or guardians directly tell children that not doing their assigned work is alright because it's effectively suggesting: "it's okay if you don't fulfil a responsibility that you are obligated to complete because, in this moment, it is an inconvenience!"

Children are innately big ol'sponges, that will absorb anything taught to them, it's a shame that even the youngest of them will learn this practice well before they can self actualize and rectify the issue (which in itself could take a matter of weeks, or years to remedy.)

Sorry this is super long.  If anyone was curious, my sample size of this problem is limited to the two locations I work for; the difference being that one is a suburban (middle - upper class) and downtown (lower - lower middle class) demographics.  Thus, the premise of my thought is solely within these given contexts - not be noted or implied at universal.  Again, thoughts, not to be misunderstood as factual by any means.

This is probably one of the very few legitimate arguments people make for right-wing philosophies. The truth is that life isn't fair, life does have a lot of random chance, and in a lot of ways you are helpless. But this shows that knowing the truth of that can be detrimental. The illusion that you can do things that seem impossible will produce better results. This is essentially the American cultural illusion that if you can only work hard enough, and reach for the stars, you'll transcend your current situation. Perhaps then, that's the real reason the country has been economically successful despite all the challenges. Because they've accidentally connected with something that is psychologically beneficial.

But of course, when we have a large portion of the population who have already learned helplessness generationally, choosing not to help them or address the issue isn't going to fix anything. Just like how it was really difficult to re-train those dogs from their habits. This is why, in my opinion, education needs to change it's priorities. Yes, kids need to know how to read, write and do basic math. But kids also need to learn life skills; we need to train specifically to grow kids initiative and give them more agency in their world. Very often in the classroom, you find that kids shut down when they're given a challenge, when they're forced to think. We must resist the urge to simplify, and resist the urge to swoop in and save the day as teachers. Help eventually, but let them struggle through things first. It's amazing what kids can achieve when they're given that space, and how much their confidence grows when they figure it out.

Intent has a big effect on how uncomfortable an annoyance is perceived to be and how distracting it becomes. If you believe there’s malevolent intent behind what is causing your discomfort, the discomfort is greatly magnified. If you believe the discomfort is caused be something that is under no one’s control, it’s minimized almost to the point of acceptance.
